speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I do so somewhat reluctantly. I feel it is important to raise in the House at the earliest possible moment a matter that I believe is of considerable importance. It may in fact constitute a grievance. It may even be a question of privilege at some future date.
As you know, Sir, it has been the practice in the House of Commons to establish the need for the presence of both government and opposition in order to conduct business. I recognize that it may not be absolutely necessary under certain circumstances, but the practice has always been that, for the business of the House to be conducted properly and adequately, there would be representation both from the government and from the opposition at the start of the business of the day. I suggest this practice has been a good practice, one that has resulted in a harmonious relationship in the House of Commons which in turn has resulted in the House being able to deal with questions in a way which brings about their resolution.
At the moment, there appears to be a deviation from that practice, if not in the House itself, in the committees of the House. I would ask Mr. Speaker if he would consider motions that were put in committee-given that the committees have the right to establish their own rules of procedure, they must do so within the generally accepted framework of the rules of procedure of the House of Commons-that have resulted in the establishment of a practice which could disrupt the orderly procedures both in the House and in the committee. In a number of committees, decisions have been made by the Government members that a quorum shall be established based not on the normal practice of representation from both sides, but-
May I be clear that the Hon. Member is in fact raising a question relating to practices in committees? Does the point of order relate to that issue?
Mr. Speaker, I am raising the practices that have been pursued in the past.
In committee?

The committees are an emanation of the House. The committees operate by the same rules as the House of
Commons. They do not set separate rules. They may set with unanimous consent, as can the House, different rules, practices and procedures, but only with unanimous consent.
I suggest that what is happening is going to cause grievous difficulty not only in the committee but in the House. All I am asking is that there be some attempt made to ensure that the practices that have been followed, both in the House of Commons with regard to quorum and in the past in committee with regard to quorum, be followed during this Parliament. At the moment I have reason to believe that is not the case.

The Member may have reason to believe that is not the case. The Member is an experienced parliamentarian. He knows the traditions of the House are that the Speaker has no right to intervene in procedures or decisions taken in committee. The committees are masters of their own affairs. The Hon. Member knows well enough that the issue that he is raising may at first blush be an issue that the procedural committee or a committee on reform of the House may want to consider.
The rulings in the past with regard to these questions have been very clear. The committees are master of their own destiny. An appeal from a decision taken in a committee shall be made in the committee to the chair of the committee and, if necessary, resolved in the committee, but cannot be brought before the House. The Speaker has no authority to decide on something that has happened in a committee unless it is reported by the committee in its report to the House. Only in that circumstance does the Speaker have any capacity to deal with a question or a grievance or a point of order that the committee has dealt with. I think the Hon. Member knows that.
I regret to find that, while he may have a point of serious concern, and I appreciate the point he is making, I cannot at the moment find that it is a point within the grounds of a point of order in the House. I therefore think that the matter should end at this point. However, the Hon. Member for Hamilton Mountain may have a supplementary comment. That is certainly my current view and I am prepared to rule in that manner unless the Hon. Member has something else to say.

Mr. Speaker, I do not deny for a moment the validity of the comments you have made; neither do I question them. My concern is that I may well find it necessary to attempt to raise a question of privilege.
My problem is that the practice that is being followed will cause disruption in the House of Commons as it will cause disruption in committees. That worries me. I raise the matter

November 22, 1984
Ways and Means
since it is of worry to me and I alert the House to the fact that there are problems in committees.
I think I should leave the matter as I indicated earlier. I feel that a point of order for the purposes of the House has not been established.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, we agree. We have no objection to the Bill being referred to a Committee of the Whole or to considering all stages today. There may, however, be someone on our side who will be speaking to the Bill.

Mr. Speaker, I would like at the very outset to express my appreciation to my House Leader, as well as to the respective House Leaders of the two Opposition Parties, and particularly to the agricultural spokesmen of the two Opposition Parties, for their understanding and co-operation.
It is with concern for a group of financially hard-hit farmers that I wish to speak briefly this morning. Those particular farmers are tobacco growers and their plight is a common one. They are caught in a very significant cost-price squeeze between rapidly rising input costs, dramatically lower prices and some very significant tobacco acreage cuts. As a result of this, tobacco growers have studied their marketing situation. They have assessed their options and have approached the federal Government with a request. It is in response to their request that I am introducing today for second reading Bill C-4, a Bill to amend the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act.
This piece of legislation would simply amend the Act to include tobacco as a commodity which may be regulated by supply-management provisions. I want to stress that it is, however, only a facilitating piece of legislation. While the amendments would not immediately provide for a national supply management agency for tobacco, they would allow growers to explore the possibility of establishing such an agency.
Specifically, the legislation would designate tobacco as a farm product for which an agency could fix and determine the quantity of product which could be marketed in interprovincial or export trade circles. The Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act currently restricts the application of supply management to eggs and poultry and their products. At the present time, tobacco production is regulated by provincial marketing organizations and tobacco prices are negotiated between those provincial agencies and the buyers. However, tobacco growers want the legislated ability to work together on a national basis and to act in a unified manner. Surely they are entitled to the same rights as egg and poultry producers if they so wish.
It is well known, Mr. Speaker, that tobacco production was once one of the most lucrative sources of farm income not only in the Province of Ontario but, indeed, in the four other
Farm Products Marketing
producing provinces in Canada. However, that is no longer the case. The domestic market for tobacco has been steadily declining while production and input costs have continued to increase. Domestic demand for tobacco has declined by some 20 per cent since 1983. As a result of these factors, Ontario growers expect to take a significant loss on their 1984 crop. At the moment estimates of that loss run between $50 million and $60 million and it may well exceed the $60 million figure. A loss of that magnitude, of course, is more than just a loss to the farmers. It means a loss of employment for some 5,000 migrant workers and university students who rely on the tobacco harvest to get them through the winter or through their next term at university.
There is as well the impact on the local communities. When tobacco growers do not have any money to spend it affects not only farm machinery and car dealers, but grocery and department stores, travel agencies, indeed virtually every commercial operation in the community.
The tobacco industry has been good for Canada and for tobacco farmers. What makes it extremely significant, Mr. Speaker, is that the amount of tobacco moved out of the farm gate on the average tobacco farm, whether it be in Ontario, Quebec, Prince Edward Island, Nova Scotia or New Brunswick, contributes somewhere in the vicinity of $1 million to $1.5 million in tax revenue to the two levels of government. Tobacco is a big earner of foreign exchange and it brings in well over $100 million a year.
Of course, many people applaud the decline in smoking and the beneficial impact it will have on the health of Canadians, but we also must recognize that tobacco is an important crop in international markets and Canadian farmers grow some of the best in the world. The researchers at our Delhi research station have worked closely with growers over the years and have been extremely successful in developing new varieties of tobacco which are lower in tar content. They have assisted in developing production techniques and labour saving equipment. At present they are also working on alternate crops that may assist growers to diversify and reduce their tobacco production without accompanying losses of income. That has always been the case, Mr. Speaker, but realistically, although no comparable substitute has been found, we must strengthen our resources, both financial and human, in this direction in the future.
Again realistically, Mr. Speaker, this will not be an easy task. A farmer with 100 acres of sandy soil could make a good living growing 30 or 40 acres of tobacco in rotation with other crops. However, those 100 acres will not earn a living for the farmer if he only grows corn and soybeans. Unfortunately, soil that is ideal for tobacco production is not particularly good for most other crops without a dramatic increase in the use of fertilizer.
Tobacco growers are going through a crisis and they believe a national agency is necessary to help them stabilize their industry. Some critics have suggested that the supply manage-

November 22, 1984
Farm Products Marketing
ment provisions of the Act should be opened up to include all other agricultural commodities as well. However, today we are concerned only with tobacco because of the urgent cost-price problems of tobacco production and because producers are seeking this change themselves. In contrast, producers of some other commodities have reservations about having the Act altered to include their products and I share that view.
The legislation to amend the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act was one of the final pieces of legislation considered in the House before it rose last summer. It is worth noting that this Bill is one of the first Bills to be introduced in this new Parliament. It demonstrates very clearly the commitment of this Government to amend the Act on behalf of the tobacco producers in Canada.
I urge Members of this House to support Bill C-4 and encourage its speedy passage. Once the Bill is passed the National Farm Products Marketing Council may hold public hearings to explore the possibility of establishing a marketing agency for tobacco, and negotiations would then be held with provincial signatories to work out details of the actual agreement. It is only fair and reasonable that tobacco producers should be allowed to look into the option of playing a larger role in the marketing of their own product.
In conclusion, I would like to draw to the attention of the House that I have had brief discussions with my counterparts in the two other Parties with reference to a slight drafting problem. Perhaps it would more accurately be described as a bit of a conflict or another legal opinion with reference to making a further slight amendment to the Bill. In the section of the Bill that we are amending we are placing the word "tobacco" in line 9, and line 10 goes on to refer to "the products of'.
We were satisfied by legal advice which we received from our own Department that the simple insertion of the word "tobacco" would cover parts of tobacco. However, to be consistent with the Bill, there is some question as to whether we should again insert the word "tobacco" in line 10 as it relates to products of. My two counterparts appear to be receptive to this. Although I have to be guided by the Chair, I understand that if the agreement holds true, as I am certain it will, rules dictate that it is not possible for me to move the second amendment. However, I understand that another Member of this Party could put this amendment forward. I expect that my colleague, the Member for Haldimand-Norfolk (Mr. Bradley), will be in the House at committee stage, and I would like to serve notice now that this second amendment will be moved at that time.

Mr. Speaker, I am happy to have an opportunity to speak on Bill C-4, a Bill to amend the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act. I would like to congratulate the Minister on his appointment as Minister of Agriculture. He is a gentleman whom I have known since our days at the University of Guelph. He is a man who has
demonstrated his concern and interest in the agricultural community of this country over the past many years.
I would like to indicate our support for the Bill before the House today which adds the commodity of tobacco to those commodities which can have a national marketing agency in our country. The tobacco producers in southwestern Ontario, Quebec and the Maritimes have indicated their support for this Bill. They have indicated how desperately important it is for them in the marketing of their products, as it was for other commodity groups that have taken this step in their marketing procedure in the past. We understand the problems they face with a commodity for which the demand is dropping each year. We understand as well the problems they face in dealing with multinational corporations which travel around the world playing one set of producers against another in various countries.
If this legislation is passed it will allow producers to control their production. This will allow Canada to set limits on imports from other countries. I understand imports have fluctuated from below 8 million pounds a year to as high as 15 million pounds. Such violent fluctuations of imports will be controlled with supply management imposed on our own producers.
We agree with this legislation. We agree with other commodity groups having the opportunity to establish marketing agencies as well. We wonder why Bill C-56 was not reintroduced. That Bill would simply have removed the section from the Act and made it possible for all commodity groups within which the majority support a national marketing agency to take the same step. We wonder why the Government is limiting this to tobacco. There are other groups facing difficulty in the country. When the majority of the producers of a commodity want to establish a marketing agency and present a plan to the National Farm Marketing Council which is accepted by the Government, they should have the opportunity to take the same step. However, this Bill limits it stricty to tobacco.
My concern is with regard to why we are debating this Bill today. The Bill was filibustered last June 29, the last day that the House sat in the previous session. From reading a report in the London Free Press it is clear that the Tory House Leader spent a lot of time that day talking about many other things, effectively killing Bill C-56 which would have allowed this agency to be established. By this time it would have been established for five months. The tobacco farmers certainly vented their wrath at that time. The report of the London Free Press of June 30, 1984 states:
Irate tobacco farmers surrounded Conservative MPs outside the House of Commons chamber Friday and accused them of killing a bill that would have enabled establishment of a supply management agency.
The article goes on to mention that the tobacco farmers had met in the morning with the Minister of Agriculture and the Conservative caucus. The article continues:
Liberal House leader Yvon Pinard offered to add 15 minutes to debate time but his Conservative counterpart, Ray Hnatyshyn, refused it, insisting instead
November 22, 1984

that the House not set a limit on debate time. Liberal MPs and apparently the farmers believed the Tory tactic was used to stall the bill.
Outside the chamber, farmers were seething.
The report goes on to indicate that the PC Member for Haldimand-Norfolk (Mr. Bradley) said later:
"I'm going to be thinking about my future in this place over the weekend." Bradley, one of the chief proponents of the bill in the Tory caucus, was bitterly disappointed by the turn of events.
Although we are glad to see this Bill passed today, Mr. Speaker, we feel that it really should have been passed last June 29. The Tory handbook and election campaign included an item which indicated that they would support farmers in the efficient development of marketing systems of their choice. If that was part of the Tory platform, we wonder why Bill C-56 was not passed as proposed. It would have allowed all commodity groups to establish a marketing system of their choice.
Although marketing is of the utmost importance, I suggest we should be providing this kind of assistance to other commodity groups. We want this legislation to be passed. We also want the Government to introduce legislation to deal with the urgent cost-price squeeze being faced by other commodity groups such as the red meat industry and the grains industry. Their situation is perhaps more crucial in terms of that cost-price squeeze than at any time in many years. One has only to read the report of the Farm Credit Corporation which indicates that some 39,000 producers are facing very critical financial times. In fact, 1,700 producers are facing financial collapse.
The Speech from the Throne contained no proposals to deal with our important resource industries of agriculture, mining and forestry or with tourism. According to the economic statement of the Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson), the question of agri-bonds will simply be referred to the Standing Committee on Agriculture. There is no legislation forthcoming to allow the Farm Credit Corporation to provide set-aside provisions. There is no legislation forthcoming such as there was in the Bankruptcy Act to provide for pre-bankruptcy arbitration.
We do not see any activity to lower the cost of money for farmers as was promised in the Conservative campaign platform, or set-aside legislation such as was introduced in the United States with respect to their farmers' home administration. That legislation permits them to set aside a portion of outstanding loans in cases of an individual who is a good producer and is capable of meeting his commitments if he could have a little short-term relief. It is a very ingenious arrangement applying to the commercial banks as well and I believe similar legislation here is urgently needed.
Since these measures have not been announced in the Speech from the Throne or in the economic statement, I am concerned that such legislation is a long way off. Consequently, those 1,700 farmers who are facing bankruptcy this winter will not get any relief.
Farm Products Marketing
The Official Opposition recognizes the urgency of this matter and we support this Bill. The production level of tobacco is dropping precipitously and those producers are facing a monopolistic situation with the international corporations that buy tobacco from ouside the country. We want to see this legislation passed so that this group of producers can work together to address this declining situation.
We hope that the Government will provide the additional research assistance in the hope that some of them will adopt their land and production techniques to meet other opportunities for agricultural production in the months and years ahead. With that, I want to indicate our support to see this Bill go to the Committee of the Whole.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to take part in this debate on Bill C-4 to amend the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Act. It will have the effect of permitting tobacco producers to include their product within a marketing plan that will limit the amount of production that is permitted into the country or the amount produced on the farms.
This amendment concerns part of the Marketing Agencies Act which has its roots back in the 1930s. It was a copy of initiatives taken by those in Australia and New Zealand who were looking for methods that would permit their farmers to have similar powers that the state granted to large corporations and to workers to set up labour unions. The purpose of that legislation was to allow agricultural producers to put their products on the market through a single desk-selling agency. In some instances it also provided for a reduction in quotas, the setting of quotas to regulate the amount of product put on the market and even the amount of product produced in some cases.
I am concerned about this section of the Act because I believe it is rather unfair that it prescribes a limitation to producers at all. In any event, this proposal will limit the amount of imports or production in the country to only three groups of producers. They are egg producers, producers of poultry or similar products and now tobacco producers. I will come back to this subject because I believe it is a negative imposition of a set of rules and guidelines that are an unnecessary hardship on agriculture. I will prove that by illustrating how our existing legislation already provides sufficient safeguards without forcing producers to jump through another hoop.
The House is aware that tobacco farmers have been required to lobby for the last two years, including having to picket in the rain for several weeks last spring. The silly attitude taken by various governments forced them to lose another season of benefits from this proposed legislation. After two years, many of them are no longer able to remain in business. They have been forced to come to the House of Commons, hat in hand, to get permission to use that last bit of regulation which would allow them to stay in business.
This type of procedure is no longer required for corporations. We long since gave up sitting in judgment on whether a
478

November 22, 1984
Farm Products Marketing
group of individuals should be allowed to form a corporation. We no longer require such a lobbying procedure by a group of workers in order to set up a union. This is all accomplished through Order in Council according to very clear procedures. Unions and corporations can be set up almost instantaneously.
However, the producers of any agricultural products other than eggs, poultry and tobacco, after today, must go through a long process of bargaining with the Government, lobbying Members of Parliament and even picketing occasionally. This often results in havoc being weaked on the industry before getting a lawful right which should naturally be theirs.
National products marketing agencies are set up in two stages in this country. That in itself is a fairly rigorous hoop to jump through. First, producers must organize on a provincial basis. Depending on the provincial organization, a majority of producers in most provinces-as much as two-thirds majority in some-must agree on a marketing plan. But that is not all. After havig organized themselves within their province, they still do not have powers to regulate the sale and marketing of the product for interprovincial trade or for international export trade. In order to do that, they have to go to the national legislation. They have to prove, depending upon the requirement, that from 50 per cent to two-thirds of producers are proposing to become part of the national legislation.
One can imagine the way in which the political process works in farm organizational terms. To reach that point they have probably spent five years or six years but are not in a position to regulate the amount of product going into the market or to regulate imports of the product. Then they have to convince the Government to introduce a Bill before the House of Commons. This requires the Government finding time in the House to debate the Bill so that it can be passed through all stages and proclaimed. At that point they finally get what they set out to do. As a result of the period of time required, often the initiators of the program have gone out of business. Some of them have died by natural causes. It is a long, stupid process.
In this case it would have been much better to have simply deleted Clause 17(3) from the Bill. This would have permitted producers of any product who had jumped through the two sets of hoops at the provincial and federal levels to get what they wanted initially. Again I indicate that in some cases as many as two-thirds of the producers have to be in agreement. With the deletion of that clause and producers having gone through two road-blocks, they would have been able to have those powers and to begin to function as part of the Canadian society, as is the case with large corporations and unions.
It is a discriminatory practice to continue with these limitations. We will be permitting the tobacco amendment to go through. Later on at the proper stage I should like to introduce an amendment which would in fact eliminate this particular clause of the Bill. I am not sure what Mr. Speaker's ruling will be on such an amendment since the Bill in front of us is a very short one. However, Hon. Members should look into the
procedures required to set up a marketing organization and to conduct that organization in a business-like fashion, having some control of imports and some control of the amount of goods offered on the market. Such an amendment is certainly required. If we cannot get it today, certainly we will in the near future.
There is a great deal of difficulty facing tobacco farmers in the country at the present time. There are approximately 185,000 acres of land, in southern Ontario mostly, which lends itself to the production of tobacco. It is almost too sandy to produce any other crop which yields the same amount of income. Farmers have been under pressure for a number of reasons. There is reduced demand for tobacco because of the fear of lung cancer, as well as various environmental demands of society today. They are under pressure from imports. The Minister's proposed amendment would help provide some protection from various parts of the tobacco plant coming into the country as imports. Also they are under some pressure as a result of potential substitutes and some experimentation which has been conducted with various varieties of lettuce and the processes through which that crop has been put. There is a very clear need for some control of the amount of product introduced into the market from outside the country. The farmers require the ability to continue with acreage controls which they have placed upon themselves.
The cut-backs in the industry to this point have been quite substantial. There are approximately 2,000 or more growers in the industry now. They took a 21 per cent production cut last year by agreement. This has meant approximately 5,000 fewer tobacco workers at harvest time and probably between 500 and as high as 1,000 workers no longer having jobs in the manufacturing and distribution parts of the business. Probably close to 500 of those 2,000 farm families are faced with being forced out of business. This particular change to the law will give them the power to control the amount of imports with which they are faced, but it will reduce only marginally the pressure facing the industry at the present time.
We think it is a necessary amendment to help the tobacco industry. My only regret is that the Minister did not see fit to do away with the limitation clause so that producers of all farm products, having jumped through two sets of very strict requirements at the provincial and national levels, would have been able immediately to control their products in a manner which would provide them with adequate incomes.

Mr. Speaker, indeed I am pleased to be here today representing the constituency of Oxford. Having gone through the recent election promise that we would do certain things with respect to agriculture, I am pleased that within a matter of a couple of short weeks we are able to bring before the House something for which we have been fighting for months and months. In the last Parliament the then government refused to bring forward an amendment which would have easily suited the needs of the Canadian tobacco industry.
I will not become involved in a long dissertation about the steps which took place going back almost a year now. At the
November 22, 1984

wish of a large majority of tobacco producers, approaches were made to the government. It promised to have an appropriate Bill in the House within a few weeks, and then within a few months. One promise after another was made. Finally, by the end of June the Liberal government had broken several of its commitments to the tobacco industry. The Bill was brought in at the last minute, not even as a priority. It was about fourth on the list for one of those last days. As a result of that deliberate attempt by the Liberal government, the Bill did not pass.
Tobacco growers in southwestern Ontario were concerned about that. I will have to modify what I say somewhat because it is fair to say that the majority of tobacco growers wanted a simple amendment passed which would allow the inclusion of the word "tobacco" in the federal Marketing Agencies Act. As it was, a significant number of growers had reservations about it. However, it was certainly the feeling of the Progressive Conservative Party that producers of the country should have an opportunity to decide whether or not they wanted to be involved in a national marketing board. Our intent last year during those preliminaries leading up to the introduction of the Bill in the House was for tobacco growers to have that opportunity. That is all we asked. We wanted the former government to give them the privilege, as producers producing a particular commodity, of deciding how they would like to go. The next step would follow according to what they decided. As we all know, it was not possible with the attitude of the former government to do that. It brought forward a complicated Bill. It was not a simple Bill that could be voted on in a hurry, the way we can here today. As a result, it did not pass.
Agriculture, of which tobacco is a significant component in this country, is one of the basic components of our economy. Whether we are on the Government side or Opposition side, I sometimes wonder whether we really understand the significance of agriculture as the basis of our Canadian economy.
I have occasion to meet from time to time with repesenta-tives of the Federation of Agriculture, in my constituency the Oxford Federation of Agriculture. They continually impress upon me the importance of the agricultural sector. No matter which side of the House we are on, all of us must bear in mind that even though we are pretty well agreed on the need for some cuts in our over-all economy in order to get at the deficit problem, we have to look very seriously at whether we can afford to cut very significantly in the agricultural area.
As it is now, the input costs of most farmers, whether they are in tobacco or any other field of agriculture, are far in excess of what they used to be, more so than their revenues. As a result, farm incomes have dropped in an absolute manner from five years ago. The agricultural community across this country is suffering as much as, if not more than, many of the other economic sectors. We had better look very seriously at to what extent we can afford to limit support for the agricultural community in Canada.
Farm Products Marketing
One of the most important commodities in my constituency of Oxford is tobacco. The Town of Tillsonburg, which is known as a tri-county town, lies in the constituency and County of Oxford. It touches the border of Haldimand-Nor-folk. It is within a mile or two of the constituency of the Minister of Agriculture (Mr. Wise), which is Elgin. Tillsonburg is the headquarters for the Ontario Flue-Cured Tobacco Growers Marketing Board.
The amount of tobacco grown in Oxford is not as great as the amount grown in Haldimand-Norfolk. My estimates are not precise to the nearest decimal point, but approximately 60 per cent is grown in Haldimand-Norfolk, 20 per cent in Oxford, and 20 per cent in Elgin. Smaller amounts are grown in Durham-Northumberland. On a national basis, small amounts are also grown in western Quebec, Prince Edward Island, Nova Scotia and New Brunswick. If my recollection is correct, 90 or 95 per cent of all tobacco produced in Canada is produced in the area around Tillsonburg.
If I were here today to defend the dairy farmers of this country, I could cite many proud facts which have a bearing on this tobacco Bill as well. In these stressful times being experienced by the farming community, those farmers perhaps least stressed are the dairy farmers. In the last three years I have received very few letters from dairy farmers indicating problems, with the exception of young men and women wanting to get into dairy farming who are having difficulty finding money to purchase the farm and quota. We must ask ourselves why the dairy farmers are having less problems.
By way of an aside, I am proud to speak of the dairy industry in my area. Although the constituency of Perth, and my friend and colleague from Perth (Mr. Brightwell) will understand and agree, has more cows than we have in Oxford, what is interesting is that we produce more milk. I do not know whether that suggests that we have better farmers in Oxford. I would not want to say that. Maybe they are better farmers in Perth. However, we have expertise which allows them to be the highest producers of milk of any constituency in this country.
They have had some help. Not only do they have ideal land conditions, a very temperate climate and so on which is conducive to dairying, but they have good organizational skills. The Ontario milk marketing plan provides for them, along with what is provided through the Canadian Dairy Commission, the opportunities to market their milk in a satisfactory manner. This has prevented them from suffering quite as much as other farmers have from the economic downturn in recent years.
Tobacco growers have observed this. It does not take a very acute mind to see that dairy farmers, both in Oxford and across this country, have done reasonably well over the last while. We should give some credit to the fact that they have had in place a national and provincial plan which has given them the opportunity to market their milk in an orderly fashion. It has provided them with returns that are reasonable, certainly in comparison with other commodities.

November 22, 1984
Farm Products Marketing
On that basis, I rise today in support of Bill C-4 which represents an attempt by tobacco producers across this country to gain some of the opportunities the dairy farmers have had. There may be some resistance to this from other parts of the country. I am not here today to get involved in that kind of an issue or conflict. I am here to speak on this Bill and also to do so on behalf of the producers who I know are anxious to have this Bill passed as quickly as possible. These producers are working and trying to earn a living under desperate conditions in the constituencies of Elgin, Haldimand-Norfolk and Oxford. As I mentioned earlier, I am proud to state that the headquarters for this constituency are in Tillsonburg in the constituency of Oxford.
I have received representations from constituents asking why the Member for Oxford, who himself does not smoke, is trying to support the tobacco industry when he is a physician and should be opposed to the use of tobacco. I understand their concerns. As a physician, I realize that there are definite health hazards from the use of tobacco. I accept that. As a physician, I am convinced that that is the case. However, I remind these constituents who write to me in this vein that, be that as it may, I still represent the tobacco farmers in Oxford. They are involved in the legal business of the growing of tobacco. There is nothing illegal about it. I have an obligation to them and I indeed want to support anybody who has a problem that should be aired in the House of Commons and L may be of assistance to them.
A number of things have happened that make it difficult for the tobacco growers, and this makes me want to speak today on their behalf. For instance, in the past both the federal Government and provincial governments have deemed it fair and wise to impose extra taxes of one sort or another on the tobacco industry largely at the retail level. By so doing, these governments are greatly increasing the amount of tax to which that particular industry is subjected in an over-all sense. I sometimes ask myself whether or not that is quite fair.
There are various approaches one could take to influencing people in their daily habits. Whenever 1 get to my medical office, which is very seldom these days, I try to influence people not to smoke or certainly to cut down on their smoking for health reasons. That is fair enough. I believe it is fair enough for those of us, either collectively as governments or as individuals, who are convinced that tobacco is a health hazard to try to influence people that it is probably not wise to smoke. I have no difficulty with that.
However, when it comes to taxation of the tobacco sector, 1 want there to be some fairness and equity. The way we should be exerting that kind of influence on people is through an educational process at the federal and provincial levels and through the various health groups. I do not want to see the Government indulging in over-taxation which is discriminatory to one particular sector.
It is a pleasure for me to be here today because we now have a Government that is prepared to look after the interests of the
farmers of the country. The Government has now selected this one particular sector which the previous government refused to help and we have before the House today Bill C-4, a Bill which I am fully prepared to endorse. I hope my colleagues on both sides of the House will see the wisdom of this very simple amendment that will hopefully make the lives of tobacco growers much more acceptable to them.

Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to rise in the House to speak to this Bill. I must say I am also very pleased to see that my colleague, the Hon. Member for Algoma (Mr. Foster), and the Hon. Member for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell (Mr. Boudria) are in the House. We had a little discussion yesterday on absenteeism in another context, and I am very happy to see they are here today.
Mr. Speaker, I think it is important to remember that the Bill we are considering is not one of the Bills that were tabled in the House before, whether it was a year or six months or three months ago. We are not considering those Bills. We are considering a Bill tabled by the Hon. Minister of Agriculture (Mr. Wise), and I think the debate should focus on this particular Bill and not on previous Bills. Of course I am not as experienced as the Hon. Members to whom I referred earlier, but nevertheless, I feel that as the Hon. Leader of the Government (Mr. Hnatyshyn) just mentioned, the important thing is that we have a Bill that is, after all, a minor one and concerns a single word, and I think that if we really want to help Canadian farmers, we should expedite this legislation and

November 22, 1984
Farm Products Marketing
refrain from obstruction and from going through the whole history behind this legislation. There may have been previous debate on the question, but now we should adopt this new legislation as quickly as possible.
Mr. Speaker, this week, in the presence of the Hon. Minister, I had an opportunity, to meet producers in this sector from the Province of Quebec. Various groups of tobacco growers may have expressed some concern in the past, but I can assure the House that the legislation proposed by the Hon. Minister of Agriculture has taken into account the comments of Quebec farmers and, if I may say so, the concerns they have raised previously. In fact, they are quite pleased and they agree with the Bill now before the House, and although growers in Quebec and the four Atlantic provinces represent only a small percentage, namely 7 per cent, of Canadian tobacco growers- 93 per cent are from Ontario-it would seem that the fears that such a program would have an adverse impact on the smaller growers across Canada are unfounded. Everyone seems to agree with the legislation.
It is too bad that the criticism we are getting concerns debates in the previous Parliament. I feel that if we agree with the present legislation, we should decide to adopt it as soon as possible. Mr. Speaker, as I said earlier, my parliamentary experience is far from extensive, but to me, if a Bill is on the Table of the House and Hon. Members agree with its content, it should be passed as quickly as possible. Mr. Speaker, I am appealing to common sense, not to parliamentary procedure. I support this Bill. It is the first Bill introduced by the Minister of Agriculture, and I think we should proceed quickly with its passage, and then go on to something else, because Canadians, whether they are farmers or active in any other sector, expect a great deal from this Government, and that is why I think it is important that we should proceed quickly with these minor details so that we can deal with the really important problems facing us.

Of the Bill.
November 22, 1984

In that case, I have a number of questions I would like to put to the Minister concerning the Bill. The Bill does not really deal with a number of concerns which have been expressed by various groups in the country; for example, the idea of strengthening the powers of the National Farm Products Marketing Council, of making that council stronger and more in control of the individual agencies and perhaps having more responsibility right back to the Government itself.
I had the opportunity last year of working on the Crown corporations Bill and its provisions which required greater accountability and reference not only to the Minister and to the Government but to Parliament itself. This was done so that Crown corporations would have a responsibility to put before Parliament on a regular basis their corporate plan. They would have a budget which would have to be approved by the Government. They would have annual reports, and so on, and there would be a continuing flow of information ultimately to Parliament. It has been said that the National Farm Products Marketing Council does not have much control over the agencies nor are they ultimately accountable to the Government itself, which is then politically accountable here on the floor of the House of Commons.
I wonder if the Minister agrees with that view, which has been expressed by many groups in the country and by, I believe, some provincial agencies and legislatures as well, and whether he foresees a need for greater financial accountability as well as just the over-all supervision by the National Farm Products Marketing Council. I ask that question because much of the previous legislation before the House provided for that in the way in which the estimates will be coming before the House in much more detail. Does the Minister feel that those kinds of amendments are ultimately desirable?
I would also like to know why the Bill only covers tobacco rather than other farm commodities. There are other groups in our society, such as consumer groups, which would like to see more accountability to Government so that the Government can respond to criticism of individual agencies. Could the Minister comment on that aspect of the legislation?

Mr. Chairman, I certainly welcome the opportunity to comment on the intervention and comments made by my colleague, the Hon. Member for Algoma. Indeed, what the Hon. Member is talking about is the same thing we are now discussing with reference to a Bill to be brought forth in the future regarding financial accountability and more or less authority for the supervisory body, the National Farm Products Marketing Council.
These are things which concerned our Government, as well as myself as Minister of Agriculture, back in 1979. Indeed, some discussions and meetings were held-not many, but a few-on that very subject between myself and the chairperson-who still occupies the chair quite capably-of the National Farm Products Marketing Council. However, of course, political events overtook us during that time. I know that discussions have been held with my predecessors, the council and the three agencies which fall within the authority of the National Farm Products Marketing Council. It was some of
Farm Products Marketing
those problems which the previous government tried to address in the final days of the last Parliament.
I believe there was a message there. One cannot move on legislation of that kind, particularly legislation which removes power which has been in the hands of the three existing national boards, without full consultation and some type of agreement. That is what we do not want to duplicate here today.
I agree with the Hon. Member that these matters must be addressed, and I can assure him that I hold them in high priority; but I have not had ample time in which to look into these matters. I have had one discussion with the chairperson of the National Farm Products Marketing Council. In fact, I am meeting with one of the national agencies this afternoon.
That piece of legislation is an important piece of legislation. The work of the council is indeed also very important because it involves supply management, the producers, the industry, the consumers, the federal Government and the provincial governments. The federal Government, the commodity groups and the provinces are signatories to those national plans. I have met with my provincial counterparts on two occasions and we have discussed some of the possible changes which should take place in that Act. However, I am not going to move unilaterally. I am not going to move prematurely regarding those issues which my colleague, the Hon. Member for Algoma, quite rightly raises. They must be addressed but discussions must be held with those people who are involved.
I can assure the Hon. Member that this will go forward. However, I want time to talk to the council members and to my provincial counterparts, and particularly to those commodity groups which are governed by that board. To this point in time I suppose I could say that we have been going full steam ahead on other things. I am not going to go into a long list of benefits which have been flowing and will continue to flow to the agri-food industry. If I did that I might provoke some partisan discussion and I would prefer to avoid that, recognizing that the clock is moving on.
Am I concerned about them? Yes, I am. Do they have a priority? Yes, they have. Will they be addressed? Yes, they will.

Mr. Chairman, Section 18(3) would allow any commodity group, with adequate planning and approval of the Farm Marketing Council and the Government, to establish marketing agencies. Is the Minister opposed to removing that section?
That is one question at one end of the pendulum. The other question at the other end is this. We hear reports from time to time that this Government's philosophy and approach will be to move to deregulation, and that marketing boards and agencies are not favoured by this Government. In view of this legislation which establishes one more agency, is it the philosophy of the Government that ultimately we will move away from marketing agencies where an industry seems to be at a

November 22, 1984
Farm Products Marketing
stage where it no longer requires them? Also, will the Government move to allow any group of producers of unregulated commodities to establish marketing boards?

Mr. Chairman, I have no hesitation whatsoever in placing on the record the fact that I have no personal hang-ups or problems in removing that section. I am speaking from a personal point of view, but the fact is that that simply ignores reality. I am not about to say to people in the non-supply management areas, the producers of agricultural commodities in any part of the country, that indeed they need not be afraid of government imposing some type of a marketing system on them. There are producers of various commodities in all regions of the country who are just not satisfied with a government or minister of agriculture making that statement. I have to respect their position. We have to accommodate the people who are anxiously waiting for this type of legislation, the tobacco people, and still satisfy the concerns which are out there. I cannot understand why but those concerns are there. To say they are not is to ignore reality. So we recognize reality, we want to make progress and this is the way we are doing it.
In addition, the Hon. Member for Algoma raises the old problem of marketing boards. He comes from the Province of Ontario and knows that we have 40 or 50 marketing boards, commissions and agencies in one form or another in Ontario. Many of them are celebrating 40, 50 or 60 years of operation. He knows that across the country we have about 130 or 140 marketing boards, commissions and agencies. A lot of people think they are all under our jurisdiction but they are not. Basically there are only three under our jurisdiction and we are making provision for four. It is an old political argument, one that the Opposition Parties have worked very successfully in Ontario and elsewhere over time. If anyone questions that, they should examine the record. Every time the Opposition get into difficulty politically, they haul out the old marketing board question. They go back to the position of the Party during the national agencies' debate in 1970 and 1971, but 1 tell them to look at the position this Party has taken consistently without exception since 1976. We campaigned on that time and time and time again.
We recognize that an agency that works well for one commodity could well spell disaster for another. This Party is not about to impose any marketing system on any commodity whatsoever. However, through legislative changes we will permit commodity groups to take advantage of the Act and to decide for themselves what type of marketing system they want. If there is any doubt about that, and there should not be because hopefully in a few minutes there will be ample proof, I can take you back to 1979. We have three national boards under the jurisdiction of the council. The National Chicken Marketing Agency was first thought about in 1970 or 1971. Discussions and negotiations were held. We had an opportunity during the brief period of time we were in government, when I was the Minister of Agriculture, to proclaim the National Chicken Marketing Agency. Where do we stand on marketing boards? It is there for the world to see.

Mr. Chairman, provincial legislation essentially acts as a screening mechanism of those who apply to operate under a national marketing plan. As the Minister knows, producers in each province must first approve the principle and concept within their borders. What real function does this limitation clause perform given that producers must first decide within their province to market their products through a marketing board and then agree a second time to go to a national plan?
Given those two tests of the acceptability of a plan, why do we still have this limitation which permits producers of eggs and poultry, and now tobacco, to actually go all the way with their marketing board, so to speak? Does it not seem an unfair restriction of the rights of those producers who have already gone through the pain and organizational problems to get themselves organized and approved provincially and then federally? Now they will have to go through yet one more set of road blocks. First of all they have to agree and then find time to deal with their particular commodity. Why does he not simply recognize that there are enough ways of making certain that the majority interest is well take care of both at the federal and provincial levels? Why do we require this third step? Is he prepared to open it up further?

Mr. Chairman, the Hon. Member for Humboldt-Lake Centre raises basically the same question which our colleague, the Member for Algoma, does. Personally I have no problem with that. I think there are enough checks, balances and safeguards in the system to prevent any problems. However, it ignores the reality of the situation. In this country we still have producers of agricultural commodities who are not satisfied with that. I say again that I have no problem with that but it ignores the reality.
If we were moving forward today with those other provisions which would open it up, I am sure that the galleries would be filled. I am sure that the producers would be on the front steps or front lawn and perhaps all the way down to Wellington Street. Instead of the number of Members who are in the House now we might even have 211 here. There may perhaps be 50 or 60 Members wanting to participate. I think there is a need here. There is a group of people who want this provision, so let us go forward.
The Hon. Member suggests that we should open it up. To be honest, Mr. Chairman, I am aware of two other groups, the pullet producers for the egg industry and the pullet producers for the chicken marketing agency, that are going forward in the hopes of achieving a national plan. However, the Act provides for that. The only people I know of who are pressing for the change at this moment, and have been for the last 12 months, are the tobacco producers. We are accommodating them. If the Hon. Member is aware of two or three other commodity groups that are demanding a national plan, I want to hear about them because I do not know about them now.

Mr. Chairman, I have spoken with a number of farmers over the past 20 years on this subject. I think the
November 22, 1984

Minister has probably been made aware by producers, as I have, that there is virtually no incentive for them to begin the organizational requirements or even to begin discussions on such a board as long as the restrictions remain here at the national level. There is no point organizing themselves if they cannot get control of their product and if they know they are going to have to fight for three, four or more years to get the changes through the House of Commons. They do not see their lives being long enough to bother beginning.
The limitations contained in this Bill are doing a great deal of harm to a lot of producers of commodities who would like to see their commodity under the control of a national marketing plan. However, they realize that the condition of their farms, which may be in some economic trouble at the moment, will get even worse if they spend the time necessary to organize a national farm marketing plan. They know it will be a six, eight or ten-year program and they do not have that amount of time, Mr. Chairman. They cannot afford that kind of time. I believe that if we left the law open we would see a great many commodity groups rushing in to form provincial marketing boards with the idea of going into a national plan immediately to control the amount of imports and production they permit themselves to sell on the domestic market.
I think the circumstances should be changed so that they are treated the same as other producers of products in this country. They should be treated in the same way as people who want to form a labour union or a corporation. As I pointed out in my initial speech, we no longer require them to come to the House of Commons and jump through hoops. It does not take three or four years to set up a corporation, an association or labour union any more. There are laws which permit that to be done and the regulations are quite clear. We are discriminating against the producers of most of the agricultural produce of this country. I believe it is time we opened up the law while it is in front of us here today.

subtopic: UNITED STATES-REPORTED THREATS TO CANADIAN EXPORTS
UNITED STATES-REPORTED THREATS TO CANADIAN EXPORTS
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, recent reports indicate that United States food industry groups are planning to curtail a wide range of Canadian farm products going to that country from Canada, worth some $1.5 billion. These reports also indicate that President Reagan has lent his personal support to the United States pork producers' drive to block Canadian exports to the U.S.A. Also they have petitioned the International Trade Commission to impose countervailing duties. The value of this trade to Canadian farmers is estimated at $500 million this year. The Canadian Government should take action immediately to prevent the imposition of these duties on Canadian exports to the U.S.A. Action at the highest possible level must be taken directly by the Minister for International Trade (Mr. Kelleher) and the Minister of Agriculture (Mr. Wise), with the Reagan administration in Washington.
The Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) has portrayed his relationship with the President as one of sweetness and light. If this is really true, why has the President cut off sugar exports from Canada to the United States? Why is the U.S. Government in the process of cutting off fruit exports from Canada to that country? Why is the United States conducting investigations to cut off fish exports from Canada to the U.S.? We have to ask ourselves whether the whole love affair between the Prime Minister and the President is a one-sided relationship.
November 22, 1984

Mr. Speaker, last month Canadians learned with horror about the death of over 10,000 caribou which were swept away while crossing the Caniapiscau and Koksoak rivers on their annual migration. Native peoples of Canada in that region depend upon caribou herds for their nourishment as well as their economic wellbeing. The tragedy is made that much greater by the fact that it could have been averted.
Over 10 years ago biologist Alexander Banfield predicted that the hydroelectric project at James Bay could lead to disastrous consequences, not only for the region's caribou but for other wildlife as well. In addition, native leaders had requested, prior to the disaster, that barriers be erected to protect the herds from high waters.
It is important that the causes of the caribou deaths be clearly established. Many different reasons have been given, but none are conclusive. Therefore we ask the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney), as the Member of Parliament from the area affected, and the Minister of the Environment (Mrs. Blais-Grenier) to urge their provincial counterparts in Quebec to launch a public inquiry to establish the exact causes of the disaster in order that this never happens again.

subsubtopic: INTERNMENT OF JAPANESE CANADIANS DURING WORLD WAR
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, this Thirty-third Parliament of Canada has been summoned to the work of national reconciliation. It is my duty this aftrenoon to remind Hon. Members of a long-standing injustice that cries out for remedy by the Government of Canada.
The National Association of Japanese Canadians yesterday informed Canadians that their community was attacked during World War II for political reasons, not for reasons of national security. The Liberal Government's dispossession and internment of Canadians of Japanese descent was opposed at the time by military and police authorities who were more concerned about racist attacks on this visible minority than about any subversive activity among them.
Noble principles of democracy were trampled underfoot as thousands of Canadians of Japanese origin were taken from their homes and lost their property to Canadian government authority. This fact was recognized by the former Liberal Government which regretted what had happened. The Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney), then Leader of the Opposition, asked for more last June when he sought a formal apology from the departing Prime Minister. Now that he has the authority to offer redress to Canadians of Japanese origin, it is the solemn duty of the Prime Minister to ensure that a resolution stating a formal apology for the injustices perpetrated, and providing for proper negotiations to establish compensation, be placed before the Parliament of Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I rise to plead for an invisible minority, the middle-aged, unemployed men of Canada. Over 60,000 Canadians between the ages of 55 and 65 are receiving unemployment benefits. When added to the number of men between ages 45 and 55 in the same need, the total comes to about 200,000. That number can be expanded still more when we add those who have become too discouraged by relentless rejection to continue seeking work. Together they form Canada's largest prison. It has no walls, it has no bars. However, it holds more than a quarter million men fast. It incarcerates them by the despair that they may never work again. Together they form an unrecognized invisible minority.

Forrestall), rapporteur for the military committee, and the report dealing with science and politics as presented by Senator Tom Lefebvre, rapporteur for the scientific and technical committee.
