subtopic: MOTION TO ESTABLISH TASK FORCE ON REFORM
speechtext:
That a Special Committee of the House of Commons to be composed of Mrs. Bourgault and Messrs. Blaikie, Cooper, Ellis, Friesen, McGrath and Ouellet, be appointed to act as a Parliamentary Task Force on the Reform of the House of Commons to examine the powers, procedures, practices, organization and facilities of the House of Commons, bearing in mind the balance between the respective constitutional responsibilities and roles of the House of Commons and the Government, such an examination to include, but not be limited to, the following matters:
(a)	the permanent and Provisional Standing Orders;
(b)	the role of the private Member in the House of Commons;
(c)	the accountability of Ministers to the House of Commons;
(d)	the legislative process;
(e)	the funding, facilities and staff support services made available to Members of the House of Commons;
(/) the administration and management of the House of Commons; and
(g) the procedures and powers of Committees of the House of Commons and
the role and the use of parliamentary task forces;
That the Committee have all the powers provided to standing Committees pursuant to Standing Order 69(8);
That the Committee have the power to retain expert, professional, technical and clerical staff;
That the Committee and members of the Committee have the power, when the Committee deems it necessary, to adjourn or travel from place to place inside
and outside Canada and that, when deemed necessary, the required stafff accompany the Committee or members of the Committee, as the case may be;
That all the evidence adduced by the Special Committee on Standing Orders and Procedure and the reports of that Committee as tabled in the House of Commons during the 32nd Parliament be referred to the Committee;
That notwithstanding the usual practices of this House, if the House is not sitting when an interim or final report of the Committee is completed, that the Committee shall report its findings by depositing its report with the Clerk of the House and that it shall thereupon be deemed to have been laid upon the Table;
That the Committee be authorized to include in its interim and/or final reports drafts of proposed permanent or temporary Standing Orders drawn to give effect, if concurred in by the House, to any permanent or temporary change or changes proposed by the Committee;
That the Committee be authorized to include in its interim and/or final reports recommendations as to the implementation of any reforms proposed in the reports of the Committee;
That Messrs. Penner, Binns, Comeau, Duguay, Jardine, Ravis and Young be appointed as alternate members of the Committee;
That changes in the membership of the Committee be made only pursuant to Standing Order 69(4)(6); and
That the Committee shall report to the House finally no later than June 28, 1985.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I regard it as a great privilege to be able to move this motion. As Members of Parliament, we share the honour and duty of serving an institution which helps to bind this nation together and which helps to define and defend the rights and interests of the Canadian people.
Edward Blake, one of our predecessors in this place, described his understanding of the importance of this institution in the following terms:
The privileges of Parliament are the privileges of the people, and the rights of Parliament are the rights of the people.
It is for that reason that reform of the House of Commons is not undertaken lightly by this Government. As 1 have expressed on other occasions, the results of the September 4 election indicate that there is a public will for a change in the operations of the central institutions of government. That desire for change expressed itself in the mandate received by our Government.
However, no matter how strong the mandate, change in a democratic society must be the result of consultation and consensus. Let there be no doubt that the Government has its views with respect to the aspects of this institution that are in greatest need of reform. Indeed, there are reforms that we could undertake on a unilateral basis. But reform without consultation is no reform at all.
Thus, the action that we take today reflects the Government's belief that real progress is achieved when, as the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) has said, "First you listen, and then you act". The motion we are currently debating provides the proposed task force with the widest of possible mandates. The committee will have the authority not only to consider the rules of the House of Commons but will have the power to examine the role of the Private Member in the House of Commons and the funding, facilities and support services made available to Members.
The Government believes that it is important to ensure that the duly elected respresentatives of the people have a say in the
November 22, 1984

legislative process and that the views of all Canadians are represented in decisions which will shape the nation's future.
To ensure, therefore, that the process of reform is carried to both sides of the House and impacts upon all aspects of our deliberations, the Government is of the view that it is important that proposals for reform be the product of an all-Party review and that the opportunity is given for the widest possible consultation in the course of that review.
We have proposed the establishment of a task force because we believe that parliamentary task forces have proven to be of the proper size and flexibility to bring focused attention to the major issues on the public agenda. We are not insensitive to the fact that by creating a seven-member committee the Opposition Parties are limited to one member apiece on the task force. We have therefore taken the rather unusual step of providing for alternate members. It is our hope that the alternate members will take the opportunity to participate in the deliberations of the task force and that the task force will benefit from their input.
There may be some who feel that this task force will merely repeat the work done by the Special Committee on Standing Orders and Procedure during the Thirty-second Parliament.
It is true that the task force will have the authority to review the reports of the special committee and the operation of the provisional Standing Orders which were adopted on the recommendation of that committee. It is not surprising that almost two years to the day from the time the experimental rules were adopted such a review would be undertaken. However, this task force is expected to go much further. I was a member of the special committee, and it was a disappointment to me that that committee dealt with a fairly narrow range of matters. Its mandate was to review the Standing Orders and make recommendations for change. Unfortunately there were any number of Standing Orders that we did not have the opportunity to consider and which, because they relate to archaic procedures, are badly in need of review.
As well, the special committee was constrained to considering merely procedural issues. If our concern is to ensure that Members of Parliament and the House of Commons as a body perform a valuable function in the legislative process and in scrutinizing the affairs of government, then procedural change is but one means of achieving our objective. Equally important is ensuring that the institution runs on an efficient basis, has all powers necessary to do its job and that individual Members have the tools they require in order to make a genuine contribution.
These are the objectives of the Government, and that is why the task force will be empowered among other things to:
-examine the powers, procedures, practices, organization and facilities of the House of Commons, bearing in mind the balance between the respective constitutional responsibilities and roles of the House of Commons and the Government, such an examination to include, but not be limited to, the following matters:
(a)	the Permanent and Provisional Standing Orders;
(b)	the role of the private Member in the House of Commons;
Parliamentary Reform
(c)	the accountability of Ministers to the House of Commons;
(d)	the legislative process;
(e)	the funding, facilities and staff support services made available to Members of the House of Commons;
(0 the administration and management of the House of Commons; and
(g) the procedures and powers of Committees of the House of Commons and
the role and use of parliamentary task forces.
This is a very broad mandate and the task force will have a relatively short period of time in which to conduct its study. I am confident, however, that the members of the task force will bring their full effort to bear on this important study and that their deliberations will prove fruitful. Mr. Speaker, you will see by the names listed for that committee that we have asked among our number competent and dedicated Members of Parliament to serve, not only in terms of permanent members but, with respect to all Parties and all members, to serve as alternates to this important committee.
It is almost a truism to suggest that unless reform is undertaken early on in the mandate of a new government it will not be undertaken at all. Frankly, it is human nature that once patterns of behaviour are established they become rather hard to set aside. It is significant, therefore, that the pledge of reform took priority in the Speech from the Throne and that the establishment of this task force is one of the first initiatives undertaken by our Government in this Parliament.
Reform is not a new issue, nor is it the result of a sudden public dissatisfaction with the operations of Parliament. It is the nature of democratic institutions to be subject to public criticism, scrutiny and debate. The roles of Parliament and of parliamentarians have been the target of criticism for as long as Canada has been a nation. A couple of quotations from the last century serve to illustrate this point.
In Canada: A Guidebook in 1894, Karl Baedeker had the following to say about Members of Parliament and the institution they served:
Few of the speeches delivered in the House of Commons can be called inspiring. In fact, when not personal, they are prosaic. This can hardly be helped, for a Canadian Parliament, like Congress in the United States, deals, as a rule, with matters from which only genius could draw inspiration.
A more pointed criticism of the inhabitants of this place is to be found in an advertisement which was run by an Ottawa furrier during the 1870s. I present this for the edification of current members of the House of Commons. It reads:
Re the new government (having carefully perused the press)-it consists of: Anarchists, 17; Horse Thieves, 22; Burglars, 10; Would-be Burglars if they had the pluck, 31; Judas Iscariots, 19; Counterfeiters, 27; Forgers, 19; Highwaymen, 46; Murderers, 29; Arch-Fiends, 1.
Under the circumstances it is needless for me to say that I decline to sell my new Spring Hats (by the way, they are just opened) to any Member of the new House of Commons.
It was signed by R. J. Devlin. How little times have changed! Even in the 1870s the press had full access to the secrets of government, as it does today.
We will never be able to please all the people all the time, but we have the responsibility to try to inspire Canadians through our actions here. Also we have the responsibility to ensure that Canadians can reasonably believe that their elect-

November 22, 1984
Parliamentary Reform
ed representatives are conscientiously working to advance the public interest.
If speeches in this place sometimes appear to lack inspiration, it may not be that the matters being considered are mundane or trivial but that Members of Parliament lack the tools or the motivation to get at the substance of the issues which are before the Elouse. There are remedies for these conditions, and it is the mandate of the task force to outline those remedies.
If I might be permitted a personal observation, it often seems that everywhere but on Parliament Hill Private Members are important participants in Canadian public life. I believe that ways must be found to enhance and expand their role and importance in this place. The relevance of this institution and its continuing ability to provide the means for ordered and peaceful social and institutional change rest in no small measure on its ability to provide an important part in its functions and the exercise of its powers to as many representatives of the people as possible. I cannot overstate the importance of this aspect of the task force's mandate.
The emphasis on the role of the Private Member is also of interest when considering other aspects of the committee's mandate. For example, a review of the procedures and powers of the committees of the House of Commons is a specific part of the broad mandate of the task force. The increasing importance of the standing committees since their creation in the late sixties has been one of the most significant developments in the changing face of this institution. In considering the committees and the use of parliamentary task forces, of course the task force will be aware of the important part which Private Members have to play in these fora and will want to consider the mechanisms which can be used to enhance their role in committees.
The importance of the work done by committees in considering legislation should not be underestimated. However, the work of all committees has increased and the task force may want to consider the means by which this work can continue without conflicting with the other competing and legitimate demands placed upon a committee's time.
Respect for the institution of the House of Commons is independent not only upon the work of individual Members but also upon its organization, administration and structure. In recent years changes in the management of the House and the services it provides to its members have been undertaken. Many of these changes were the result of the excellent report of the Auditor General on the operations and management of the House. I am certain that these changes have resulted in certain cost savings and have caused the services of the House to be placed on a more regular and professional basis, which is more in keeping with practices in other public sector institutions. However, the task force may want to review these services and the changes made to ensure that they are meeting the needs of Hon. Members while at the same time ensuring that they are being delivered in the most effective and efficient manner possible.
The task force will realize that Parliament is unlike any other institution of government and must obtain and demand the highest standards of professional and discrete services to ensure its effective functioning. It is not always enough that the services available to the House and its Members meet or exceed the standards which exist in Canada's public sector because the demands which are placed on the servants of the House are often quite distinct from the demands placed on public servants.
I am sure the task force will be cognizant of these factors in its review of the services now being provided and in considering the changes which have been made to those services in recent years. May I say in passing that in my view those services are of the highest standard and are provided by a dedicated and thoroughly professional body of employees. This is a fact of which you, Mr. Speaker, can be justly proud.
In the event that the task force recommends changing or altering the services provided by the House or the organizational structure of the House, the members of the task force might also want to concern themselves with discovering the most cost effective way of delivering those services or instituting those changes. In this manner they will be able to ensure that the budget of Parliament is subject to the same restraints to which the rest of the public sector is now subject. By doing so, the task force will have done a great service, not only for the House and its Members, but for the taxpayers of Canada.
In that light, it is my hope that the task force will take the opportunity to spell out in one of its early reports to the House its anticipated budgetary requirements and its tentative agenda. I am sure that all Members of the House will be watching the activities of the task force with interest and would be grateful to be informed of the studies that the committee proposes to launch and the schedule that it intends to keep.
It will be of particular interest to the House if the task force determines that it will make use of its power to travel in Canada or abroad. As well, I am sure that Members will want to be kept informed if the task force decides to invite representations from the public or from past or current parliamentarians.
As I mentioned earlier, we have chosen the vehicle of a parliamentary task force to undertake this review because we believe that the small size of a task force lends itself both to the tackling of difficult problems and to the opening up of dialogue between Parliament and the public which it serves. In turn, the very use of task forces is a matter to which the committee will be asked to address its attention.
As the role of the standing committees changes, there may as a consequence be a changed mandate for task forces. For the time being, however, we believe that the smaller size of a task force encourages a greater spirit of co-operation among the members of such a committee. That fact is of considerable importance given the Government's objective of ensuring that whatever reforms emerge from the work of this task force they
November 22, 1984

do so on the basis of consensus among the members of ali three Parties.
I would like at this point to address an aspect of the terms of reference of the task force which I have not previously touched upon. That aspect is the balance of the constitutional responsibilities between the House of Commons and the Government. There can be no doubt that the growth of government in Canada has placed considerable strains on the traditional relationship between the roles of the Ministry and of Parliament. As Arthur Beauchesne noted in the preface to the fourth edition of his Parliamentary Rules and Forms:
Definite rules are necessary if Parliament wants to solve its two main problems: first, how to find time for disposing of the growing mass of Government business, and secondly, how to reconcile the Government's demands with the rights of the minority. The House cannot now carry on with wholly customary law-
It was 1958 when Arthur Beauchesne wrote those words, but that sentiment is, if anything, more valid and telling today.
The task force is not being asked to rewrite the Constitution. Quite the contrary. The task force is being reminded that the constitutional balance between the institutions of government exists for good reason and that reforms that affect the balance on one side of the equation require some form of compensation on the other side.
It is my view, and I hope that of the members of the task force, that the need of governments to gain passage of their legislative programs and the duty of Members of the House of Commons to hold the Government to account for its actions are not mutually contradictory. When the balance of responsibilities is working well, the result should be that legislation is improved rather than impeded by the House and that governments seek the advice and consent of Parliament when initiating new policies.
Within the context which I have just outlined, the task force is being asked to consider not only the legislative process and the role of the private Member but also the accountability of Ministers to the House of Commons. Needless to say, as a Government, we will commit ourselves to being as forthcoming and responsive in the House as possible. Nonetheless, Canadians have the right to expect that the proper functioning of their institutions of government rests on more than simple assurances of good faith.
The task force is being asked to bring forth recommendations in this regard and the House will have the opportunity to debate those recommendations. Even at this early stage, the Government is attempting to demonstrate that it is prepared not only to say the right words but to take the right steps.
My party, the Progressive Conservative Party, has long been the Party which has stood for reform of the institutions of government. For example, it was this Party which was instrumental in pushing for access to information legislation. It was this Party in 1979 that established parliamentary reform as one of the early priorities of our administration.
Nonetheless, constructive ideas which lead to real reform are not the sole preserve of any Party or any small group of Members of this House. It is with that fact in mind that the
Parliamentary Reform
Government has chosen to place the question of reform before a committee of Members and has given that task force a broad far reaching mandate to examine all areas of the powers, practices and organization of this place. It is my hope that working together, Members from all Parties will be able to propose workable solutions to the challenges facing this institution.
As Arthur Beauchesne noted, changes in the demands placed upon the institutions of government have required that we step beyond the mere evolution of customary laws and practices. Novel problems require novel solutions, and that is why we have decided not to restrict the task force to a simple review of the Standing Orders. I look forward with great anticipation to receiving the recommendations of the task force, as do all Members of the Government. As recent members of the Opposition, we are well aware of some of the systemic obstacles to the full participation of private Members.
It is my hope that as a result of the work of this task force we will be able to banish from our vocabulary once and for all the term "back-bencher". It is our objective to ensure that in this Parliament there are no back-benchers. All Members must feel that they have a full voice in the proceedings and decisions of the House. I admit that our motive is not entirely selfless in this regard. We believe that a better, more effective House of Commons will lead to a better, more responsive style of government than Canadians have become accustomed to over the years.
For all of the reasons which have been outlined in my remarks, I would simply like to close by wishing the task force the best of success in its deliberations and by inviting all Members to give their input and support to this very important committee of our House.

The Hon. Member for Sudbury (Mr. Frith).

subtopic: MOTION TO ESTABLISH TASK FORCE ON REFORM
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question to the Government House Leader, perhaps in a very circumvented way, hinges upon the desire of his Government and of all Members of the House to undergo parliamentary reform. Whose advice was it to each of the committee chairmen this morning and yesterday afternoon in the area of reduced quorums to allow the requirement that only government members need be in their place in order to hear evidence? There has been a long tradition in this House, going back some two decades, I believe.
In 1980, with a Liberal majority government, when these motions were established in committee, they were worded in such a way as to recognize the right of the Official Opposition to be present when evidence was heard. I cannot speak for

November 22, 1984
Parliamentary Reform
other committees. I can only explain what happened in the health and welfare committee. A motion was presented by the Government side which stated that for a reduced quorum for the purpose of hearing evidence, only four members of the committee need be present. I put forward a motion to amend that motion to read that a member of the Opposition as well as the Government side be present before any evidence could be heard.
1 recognize that nowhere in the Standing Orders, which are the rules and procedure which we use in the standing committees, is there anything to the effect that a member of the Opposition need be present in order to hear evidence. However, there has been a long-standing practice in this House that was broken this morning by members of the Government. I would like to know if it was the Government House Leader's instruction to those committee chairmen to follow through with that abuse of my privileges in committee or if it was done by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr. Nielsen).

speakerposition: Minister of State (Government House Leader); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
subtopic: MOTION TO ESTABLISH TASK FORCE ON REFORM
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, let me try to put this in some perspective. I think the Hon. Member for Sudbury (Mr. Frith), who has worked on many committees during the time he has been a Member of Parliament, will know that the premise upon which he bases his proposition is simply not correct. Each committee determines its own rules of procedure subject to Standing Orders which indicate the rules respecting a quorum. Once the quorum is met, each committee can consider, for the purpose of hearing witnesses, who often come long distances at some considerable personal expense, the circumstances under which evidence may be received.
As the Hon. Member knows, there is a system of transcription of all the evidence that is received. This involves the receiving of documents in support of the work of the committee. I fully acknowledge that in some instances arrangements have been made whereby a quorum will be reduced for the purposes of receiving evidence.
I have been here for 10 years and most of that time, unfortunately, has been spent in the Opposition so I know of what I speak. In some instances, there has been some provision that a member of the Opposition will be present in a reduced quorum for the sole purpose of receiving evidence and hearing witnesses. In other instances, that has not been the case at all. The arrangements made within the committee have been silent with respect to any lesser quorum, and in some instances, I am informed, there have been provisions whereby a reduced quorum has been available without any specification as to the political affiliation of any of the members on that reduced quorum.
I have heard what the Hon. Member has said. I think we will have to carry on with the committees on the basis of a mutual respect between Parties. It is a matter of concern to me that if there were to be such a provision, it is conceivable that an opposition Party could hold up the process by simply not appearing on a parliamentary committee. I would not suggest that that would be the case.
The matter has been raised. I am going to look into the situation to see what has been transpiring there. I am glad to take the matter under advisement for the Hon. Member.
I believe that under the provisions of our rules, Hon. Members receive sufficient notice of meetings. In some cases, that notice is 24 hours by agreement within individual committees. After this matter was brought to my attention, I understand that in one committee at least, there was an arrangement made at the suggestion of a member of the New Democratic Party that there be a 24-hour notice given for committee meetings.
Why do we not look at what is happening and see whether or not we can work something out? That is the spirit which I would like to bring to the House and one which I think has been manifested by my responsibilities as Government House Leader up to this point.

subtopic: MOTION TO ESTABLISH TASK FORCE ON REFORM
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I realize that I will have an opportunity to speak on this entire matter some time later this afternoon. However, I would like to point out to the Hon. Government House Leader (Mr. Hnatyshyn) that the abuse that occurred this morning in the health and welfare standing committee has also been perpetrated in every other committee. Those committees use the same formula that was put forward by the government side. I do not understand for the life of me the paranoia of the Government in this matter.
In 1980, when there was a Liberal majority Government, a majority that was far smaller than the majority of the present Government, we allowed for reduced quorum purposes in committees the wording that a member of the Official Opposition had to be present in order to hear evidence. I did not even go that far this morning. I did not even ask that the Official Opposition be present to hear the evidence; I only suggested that at least a member of an opposition Party need be present in committee to hear the evidence. The Government used the tyranny of its majority to gun down that motion by a vote of 11 to 4. I am told that that occurred not only in my own committee but in other committees as well.
What is the Government's obsession or its paranoia? Is it fearful that the 70 Members of Parliament who sit in opposition will suddenly tie up the business of Government?

subtopic: MOTION TO ESTABLISH TASK FORCE ON REFORM
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am not suggesting that paranoia is the private preserve of any Member on any side of this House. It would be quite a different thing if we were suggesting that henceforth, the membership of only one Party would be allowed to participate in hearing the deliberations. I did say that I would be glad to take the matter under consideration. We are now suggesting that we define some reasonable rules under which evidence may be received by the committees.
Because the resources of the opposition Parties are somewhat limited in terms of numbers, I have taken a number of initiatives to try to make sure that the membership of these committees will be expanded. I worked toward making a concession of which I am proud. We were able to see that the Opposition was over-represented and the Government under-
November 22, 1984

represented on committees. We made sure the opposition Parties will have more members on each committee than should technically be available to them. We have tried to do everything we can to make sure that we will not be stretching the resources of the Opposition.
We have gone along with every suggestion with respect to the composition of these committees. However, I think the Hon. Member will have to admit that there are instances in which a reduced quorum may be advisable in order to get information before a committee. If we can resolve this matter through some form of mutually satisfactory arrangement, that is well and good. I believe it is a matter of balance and I am glad to discuss it further.
I am glad that the Hon. Member raised this issue with me because he is a Member for whom I have a great deal of respect. I know that he would not be spurious in his observations and that he would not try to make a mountain out of a molehill. I am sure he is not trying to do that in this instance.
I am sure that we can arrange our affairs to make sure that the committees co-operate in a reasonably effective manner, that all Members have reasonable notice of the meetings, and that full opportunities are made available to all Members to participate in votes. We would like to make sure that people who come before the parliamentary committees of Canada are not being unduly inconvenienced in terms of time and money. We would like to try to find some reasonable consensus in terms of this small problem.
I appreciate being afforded the opportunity of speaking to this problem, and I appreciate the fact that the Hon. Member for Sudbury raised the matter. I see that he wishes to say something further.

speakerposition: Deputy House Leader of the Official Opposition; Liberal Party Deputy House Leader
subtopic: MOTION TO ESTABLISH TASK FORCE ON REFORM
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, aside from the, in my view, rather unorthodox and unfair manner in which our Members have been treated in the committees, hardly the way to treat an Opposition that has been reduced to almost symbolic numbers in this country's Parliament-and I shall get back to this-but in case the Government House Leader should leave during my comments, not that I expect to be particularly boring, but he may have other work to do in his office, I would like to point out to the Hon. Member that although he said earlier it was up to each committee to establish its own rules and procedures, although he repeated one of those adages so often used in Parliament, he will have to admit it is a strange coincidence that in every single committee, there was this same uniform resistance on the part of Government Members. In one of the other committees where I was sitting this morning, we had to argue for forty-five minutes and we had to retreat before a vote. I must say all this is very odd, and I think it is more than a coincidence.
Parliamentary Reform
As your backbencher mentioned earlier, this also happened on the Committee on Communications and Culture. Another coincidence, of course. If the Government House Leader intends to look into this matter, as he said, I wish he would examine the coincidence factor as well.
Mr. Speaker, I would say that aside from this unfortunate incident on which I intend to elaborate later on, in principle we have no objection to the creation of a special committee or task force on the reform of the House. We believe it is essential, and in fact it has been done at regular intervals. Your humble servant who has been sitting in the House since 1968 has seen a succession of such committees, which have examined the Standing Orders of the House and parliamentary procedure with a great deal of competence and made many recommendations, all of which has helped to make this institution what it is today.
We cannot but wholeheartedly agree with this Government's decision to take the same route as its Liberal predecessor and in turn establish a task force to examine the Standing Orders and procedures of the House.
Hon. Members will recall that in the previous Parliament, a very active committee chaired by the Member for Pontiac-Gatineau-Labelle, Mr. Tom Lefebvre, who can now be referred to by name since he is sitting in the other place, sent several reports in succession to this House reflecting the work done by his committee.
We owe them our congratulations and we can only hope that the new committee will show as much zeal in dealing with the various problems that await it and that it will be able to submit to the House a series of recommendations that are as sound as the work done by the committee I just mentioned.
However, Mr. Speaker, I may say that much has already been done, especially during the last two or three years, and I hope that the new committee will not try to re-invent the wheel. It would, on the other hand, do well to take a closer look at some of the Standing Orders that require clarification.
I have had the pleasure of sitting in the same chair as you, Mr. Speaker, and trying to interpret the Standing Orders in the course of the debate, as situations arose. I must admit that over the years, the Standing Orders have been clarified and are becoming easier to understand and generally speaking, easy to interpret, but. . . and I am afraid that is the extent of my euphoria with respect to the Standing Orders. There is often a regrettable lack of precision, and I imagine committee members will do well to consult the Clerks at the Table, who are well versed in the intricacies of the Standing Orders and could certainly point out to the Committee some of the points that have created problems for your predecessors in the Chair, Mr. Speaker. I think you yourself as well as the new Speaker should be asked to appear before the Committee. The only problem is, of course, that you, Mr. Speaker and your col-

November 22, 1984
Parliamentary Reform
leagues may have to spend some time reading up on past procedure and precedents to be able to understand what was wrong with the Standing Orders.
In any case, the Clerks, whose position in Parliament is less precarious than that of an elected Member, would certainly be able to make a contribution if asked to take part in the Committee's proceedings.
I hope the Committee will be an active one that will make specific recommendations, and without wishing to be nasty, Mr. Speaker, I hope the Committee will not spend its time studying and meditating, because I would not want it to follow the Government's example, which since the beginning of this session has had only one answer to the problems that have been put before it: We will study the matter.
In any case, I hope that after the short time the Committee will be allowed to study the various issues, it will be able to report to the House next June with some specific recommendations.
Personally, I have a few suggestions to make concerning the Committee's mandate. I noticed that one of the first points the Task Force will be expected to deal with is an examination of the Permanent and Provisional Standing Orders. I would recommend that the Task Force do everything in its power to maintain the new parliamentary calendar, which is established on an annual basis so that all Members know where they are with respect to leave periods and when they can be in their ridings.
Hon. Members who have been sitting in the House for a number of years will remember that it took many Members years of crusading to get this permanent parliamentary calendar. If I had only one recommendation to make to the Committee, it would be to maintain this practice, which is a great convenience to all Members.
Another point which I feel should be brought to the attention of Task Force members is the body of measures concerning the consideration of the Estimates, both in committee and in the House of Commons. Hon. Members who are now on the government benches will recall-and I heard them when I was on the other side of the House-that they were forever complaining about the way the estimates were considered in committee and in the House of Commons. For instance, they had a lot to say against the fact that the committee was forced to refer the estimates back to the House by a given date, whether its study was completed or not, so Members of the then Opposition, now sitting across the floor, can still remember that they were left fuming.
I also recall that, on the last supply day when the House is called upon to vote huge amounts in a hurry, the Hon. Member for Edmonton West, Mr. Marcel Lambert, would invariably rise on a point of order to tell the House how ridiculous he thought that practice was and how he would have liked to change it. Now that all those who used to criticize that
practice for the consideration of supply are on the other side with a majority, perhaps we can expect that changes will indeed be made to the manner in which the estimates are examined, and that is something we will be watching closely in committee.
Mr. Speaker, I notice as well that one of the points which will come under the scrutiny of the committee is the role of private Members, those whom we commonly call backbenchers. For years now, both here and outside on city streets, everybody has been saying that we must upgrade the role of Member. Those of my colleagues who have been here for a few years and were never appointed to Cabinet readily understand that the role of a Member has to be something more than being only a messenger between the electorate and the government. Unfortunately, often as a result of the limited resources at the disposal of Members, quite a few of them did very little besides acting as messengers. Now that we have many new Members sitting on the other side of the House, hopefully the committee will make sure that backbenchers on the government side will be given adequate means to be more than rubber stamps called upon to support government policies. To do that, we will have to enhance the role of Member and make it more challenging, keeping in mind the fact that this year there are ... I am told that nearly 134 new Members sit in the House for the first time in this Parliament.
I would also suggest that the committee consider the fact that a long time ago-my God, more than 20 years, we have to go back to 1958 when the parliamentary Opposition was practically reduced to a rump, as it is now. It seems essential to me that the Members who will examine the Standing Orders realize that the Opposition will find it more difficult to discharge its responsibilities, and that the committee Members do everything in their power to give the Opposition adequate means to defend the views of those who do not necessarily endorse every government initiative. We believe that the government Members will do their best to introduce good legislation over the years. That is exactly what we in the Liberal Party did when we were on the opposite side of the House. Still, time will undoubtedly come when the Opposition will have to stand up and oppose. As I recall, it was Mr. Winston Churchill who said that the role of the Opposition is to oppose. We have no intention of acting inconsiderately, but should we ever have to show our opposition, we would like to have the proper tools at our disposal.
I am thinking of adequate research budgets as one example. Another example would be a guaranteed quorum for the Opposition on standing committees of the House, which would solve the problem we had this morning and yesterday when the committees were struck. It seems to me that the Task Force should be able to provide a satisfactory solution to all these problems.
I would now like to discuss another aspect of the mandate given this special committee, and it concerns the accountabili-
November 22, 1984

ty of Ministers. I feel that even in this pristine Parliament, it may be one of the areas where there is the most room for improvement. Our brand new Cabinet already seems to have trouble answering questions. This Government is certainly not at its most accountable during question period. I remember that when our Conservative friends were on this side of the House, they often accused the Liberal Ministers of not answering the questions and of being evasive. However, if I compare the situation then with what it is today, I think the previous Government certainly has a better record. Ministers will have to start answering questions and providing the information the public is demanding, instead of hiding behind a veil of secrecy. This is also something the Committee could examine. Ministers will also have to stop gagging civil servants. They will have to lift this veil of secrecy.
With only a few minutes left, I would like to get back to the point that concerns us most, namely part (g) of the Committee's mandate which says that the Committee will be asked to review the procedures and powers of Committees of the House of Commons. Well, a lot of changes will have to be made, considering the mood in the Official Opposition yesterday and today. 1 can also inform my hon. friend the Government House Leader that the New Democratic Party Members are not very happy either. We are very concerned about the government's attitude to committee membership. Refusing to guarantee the Opposition membership on a minimum quorum smacks of dictatorship on the part of a Government with this kind of massive majority. We think it should be a matter of principle, and I think Hon. Members will have to admit that this is one of those unwritten rules. We feel perfectly entitled to demand that the Government guarantee the Opposition a place on minimum quorums in committees, because when we were on the other side of the House, the Official Opposition had that privilege, and moreover, Mr. Speaker, in committee it was always customary to recognize as the lead-off speaker a Member of the Official Opposition. It was said:
We said that lead-off speaker will always be from the Official Opposition. That is the way the Liberals used to treat the Official Opposition and the New Democratic Party when we formed the government. At no time were we heavy-handed in striking committees.
The most ludicrous arguments were used this morning, for example, by a large majority in the Standing Committee on Communications and Culture. One Hon. Member-and I will excuse him because he is a new Member of Parliament-said, "We do not want to grant you this post because we do not want to run the risk that the Opposition would boycott a meeting". Can you imagine, Mr. Speaker, that he was afraid we would boycott? Certainly, the Hon. Member shows an ignorance of what has been happening here. I have never known the Official Opposition to boycott a committee meeting in which it would hear witnesses. Who would gain when
Parliamentary Reform
witnesses come from both ends of this country, spending taxpayers' dollars to do so, if we, as the Official Opposition, boycotted the meeting? We would look silly. We could not win in the eyes of the public. No Official Opposition, not even the Tories, would dare do that. Why would these motives be imputed to us? Why should we do such a silly thing?
We thought it strange that government members of that particular committee this morning had that sort of inferiority complex, being such a giant majority with 211 Members of Parliament. It is amazing that they would be afraid of being defeated by one or two opposition Members.

Mr. Speaker, we even felt that Government Members on several committees were showing a kind of siege mentality, as though they were afraid the tiny number of Opposition Members on committee might gang up on them!
I was astonished to hear one excuse proferred by Members who voted down guarantees that have always existed for the Opposition-it was for the sake of efficiency. The thought behind this was, of course, that the Opposition might stay away from a number of committee meetings, which would delay the proceedings, I imagine, and for the sake of efficiency, they had to make sure the Government could proceed.
I still think this shows a certain contempt for the democratic process. Let Parliament be efficient, but let us not expect the Government to be as efficient as the private sector. God forbid!

I say that in sorrow because I felt at the time that it set a mood in the House of Commons that resulted in rancor and bitterness which lasted through much of that Parliament. I said so at the time and I say it again. I did not support it and I will never support such a thing. We in this Party will deal with the Government in the appropriate ways with an eye to improving the conditions for people in Canada, but never in such a way as to create a scene that will result in Parliament suffering in the eyes of the public. I can appreciate that the Government wants now to set that behind us and go on from here. The Government House Leader said that he does not look back. He is looking forward to better things, and so am I.
Having said that, I was therefore disappointed this morning when I was informed of the mood that had developed in the committees. I want to make it quite clear that it is not my view that what went on in the committees is a direct breach of the rules of Parliament, because the rules of Parliament are set up in such a way that there is latitude and leeway afforded to committees, as is afforded to the House of Commons. That is necessary in order that changing times and conditions can be accommodated. However, what happened in the committees, as I understand it, was more a breach of the confidence of the committees. It was a misunderstanding, I hope, on both sides. It was not intended to be the heavy hand of the Government coming down on the Opposition, although I can well appreciate that those who were there could have interpreted it that way given that, as my colleague, the Hon. Member for Hum-boldt-Lake Centre (Mr. Althouse), has just indicated, it was a consistent act through every committee. One could not help but come to the conclusion that somewhere in the background someone had orchestrated, or at least advised the Government membership on the committees that that would be an appropriate way to act.
I do want to see the kind of co-operation that others want to see. We will get that kind of co-operation if we are assured that the way in which committees will conduct themselves will be consistent with the way that committees have conducted and deported themselves in the past. My colleague, speaking on behalf of the Official Opposition, has quite clearly set out what some of the problems were. I felt anxious when I was told of those problems and I raised them, both in the House and subsequently with the House Leader privately, in an effort to try to come to grips with them. I am confident that, if the House Leader has any sway over the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr. Nielsen), and I am sure he does, he will be able-

speechtext: Don't presume the worst. You are too good natured for that.

speechtext:
I will presume the best, that by tomorrow this matter will have been resolved and that the membership of the
committees will be prepared to deal, as we have always dealt, in a spirit of co-operation and good humour. I will assume that the committees will work effectively together and that the Official Opposition, followed by members of this Party, will be able to participate as we have participated in the past. I will assume that there will be a recognition that, notwithstanding the numbers required for a quorum, the committees ought not to sit on matters of extreme importance without both sides of the House being represented.
I can assure the Government House Leader, and I say this on behalf of my colleagues, that we will not abuse that. We have not abused it in the past and we will certainly not abuse it in the future. We will be there to do our job as we always have been. I would like to say in addition that it is not always the Opposition that is to be blamed when things do not work well. There are times when the government is to be blamed. In the last Parliament, for example, on one occasion in the Agriculture Committee, it was the government members who decided not to show up, therefore thwarting the committee's attempts to hear evidence from the Canadian Dairy Commission on a matter of urgent importance. It was a matter the government did not really want to have heard or to discuss. I think these things must be viewed in perspective. I am confident that by tomorrow morning this matter will be resolved. If it is resolved, as I think it will be, we will go on to develop a better relationship.
With regard to the amendment to the motion, I have sympathy with the intent. However, to be honest, I am hesitant to support it. I am not suggesting that I will not, because I will think about it over the course of the afternoon. I am hesitant to advise support on this matter. It sets out the committee in a "them and us" type of atmosphere. I do not really want to see that happen. I would like to see this committee operating as the last committee operated. We should all work together for the same general good of the institution and the public. If we structure the terms of reference in such a way as to require the committee to take into account in a particular way the effect on the Opposition, rather than the effect on the Members, then I think we may, in one way or another, undermine the ongoing good work of the committee. I suggest that the Official Opposition should consider that.
I think this committee will operate on behalf of all Members. 1 have the utmost confidence in the chairman to be named. I think the chairman of the committee will prove to be a man of considerable insight, as he has always proven to be. I anticipate that he will make sure that he gives the kind of leadership which will pull the committee together to ensure that the committee will deal fairly, openly and reasonably with the problems of Members, not only in the operation of the House itself, but also in terms of how they can best serve the public they are here to represent. Therefore, I am opposed to any inhibition being added to the terms of reference.
As to the task force itself, there is no perfect system. When I spoke the last time we set a committee such as this, I said quite frankly that the parliamentary reform that was most needed at that time was a reform between the ears of the Members. It
November 22, 1984

was not necessarily structural change that was going to alter the way Parliament worked but attitudinal change. To a large degree, that is part of what I said just a moment ago about the committee structure and the way committees can be set up. If we are going to require that this committee study matters as wide-ranging as the terms of reference will permit, we need an understanding from the Government, which we did not get from the last government, that if the committee sees fit to recommend unanimously that certain things should occur, the Government must undertake the obligation to implement those things.
There is no point in our going through the exercise over and over again in an attempt to find that Utopian situation that will make everything work. It will never be that way. However, if those Members appointed to this committee do their job well and offer unanimous or near unanimous recommendations to the House which represent the views of both Government and Opposition, then there must be a clear understanding that the Government will not place those recommendations on a shelf to gather dust and become fodder for yet another study after the next election. I say that on my behalf and I hope that of the chairman and members of the committee, because I am sure that that is what they want.
Let me also say a few words about the 11 reports that came from the previous committee. That committee worked extremely hard. At one time I was the vice-chairman and we worked very hard in trying to find a compromise that would satisfactorily recognize the different roles between Government and Opposition while also guaranteeing equal access to all Members of Parliament to the institution itself. I believe that we did a very good job on that committee. Quite frankly, those 11 reports represent many hours of work and input from all sectors of the economy and the public of Canada as well as from the Members themselves.
Perhaps it will be necessary for the task force to review those recommendations in light of the new parliamentary experience. However, I hope it will not be necessary, nor can I imagine its being of any use for the task force to go back over all the old ground again. It has been gone over a number of times, the last time being only a couple of years ago.
Perhaps after a relatively speedy review of those recommendations has been made-even if that is necessary-the task force can indicate whether implementation, appropriate or otherwise, can be made. It could then tackle the new areas that need to be considered.
I suggest that there are two matters that must be dealt with if we are going to improve the operations of Parliament. First, we must ensure that Members of Parliament do in fact have access to all of the structure of Parliament and that they are able to assure themselves and their constituents that they are functioning on the most up to date and best possible information base. It may be necessary to review that sometimes attempted but seldom successful process of requiring the Crown to place more of the documentation and background
Parliamentary Reform
material respecting the decision-making process before Parliament. I know that the Government House Leader probably shares with me the view that it is important, for the purpose of having the public understand what we do, that that access be readily available. It should not be necessary for there to be a requirement to use the freedom of information process to get information that should be made available to us in any event. I hope the task force will consider that as it conducts its deliberations.
I also believe that it should bear in mind that in order to ensure an orderly process in the affairs of the country, that the system of Parliament must be protected.
In spite of what the public may think as a result of viewing us from time to time, Parliament works quite well and does provide the checks and balances. While it does not always provide all the information, it does afford an opportunity for checks and balances to exist.
Recently I spoke at a conference at which I was describing the role of the Opposition. For many people, the role of the Opposition is somewhat of an enigma. It is a role that is not easily understood. I was attempting to explain that the role of the Opposition is in fact to oppose, albeit constructively wherever possible, but by whatever means available.
Although the Opposition may be seen to be obstructionist from time to time, it is absolutely necessary to ensure that a government, particularly one with a large majority, does not proceed at a rate faster than the public is able to absorb. Its role is to ensure that as change is proposed, there is ample opportunity for input not only from Members of Parliament or through Members of Parliament but from the various groups and individuals who have a concern for what is happening. Therefore, it is the Opposition's role from time to time to stall the government in order to make sure that the information that is necessary for those who are not in Parliament to reach learned decisions is able to reach them. Once the Opposition is able and has the time to review that information, it can place those concerns back into the process or state caveats that it feels are necessary from time to time.
I know it frustrates the Government when its measures are held up for reasons that are not immediately evident. But that right and obligation to be able to slow the process down is a vital part of the parliamentary system.
I have said to some people that there is no doubt that they may get angry when we delay legislation which they want passed, but they should remember that as they want that legislation passed, there are others in society who want it held up at least temporarily because it may be of some detriment to them. Frequently the shoe fits on the other foot. People must recognize that. I hope that the task force, through its chairman, will take this into account as it contemplates changes either to the Standing Orders or to the procedures of Parliament.
It should remember that there are times when it appears that the Opposition is delaying a measure that is of very little consequence. While the explanation for that delay may not be

November 22, 1984
Parliamentary Reform
readily understood, there is a reason. A reason for this delay in the past has been that the next piece of legislation or one further down the list is particularly contentious in nature. Therefore, it is an attempt to allow time for more input into the contentious legislation.
This is all part of the planning in the day-to-day operations of the House of Commons. It is an example of the collective planning we do in this caucus and what was done collectively in the Conservative caucus when they were in Opposition. No doubt, it is an example of what is done in the Liberal caucus. This process must be understood by Members on both sides so that we do not undermine Parliament by leaving the impression that such a delay tactic is destroying the parliamentary process, when in fact it strengthens it.
The problem as I have seen it in my time here is that parliamentarians-next to certain jaundiced journalists perhaps-are our own worst enemy. We do not defend the system. We do not defend Parliament from the criticism that is unjustified and unwarranted. While we can be justifiably criticized for a number of things that we do, I do not think it serves us well as Members of Parliament to become part of the uneducated, carping criticism that is unfounded.
I say to new Members in particular, but also to some Members who have been here before, that it is you and I who are the custodians of the process. We must understand and learn the process. We must understand how it works and why certain things are done so that when we are challenged with questions about why there are delays or problems within the process, we can at least understand how the process works and why it may be necessary for Members to use that process on various occasions to make sure that everyone in Canada can have proper access to Parliament and to the Government.
I have sat here on many occasions when members of the last government-and I have sat in Queen's Park under Conservative governments-wanted to ram things through. I can remember saying on numbers of occasions that it would be wrong, that a gestation period was required, that there were people who had not yet become aware of the importance of the legislative change, and that as they become aware of it they would want to have input into it, and that time must be taken in reviewing and considering it. Yet government members went ahead and pushed it through anyway because they had a narrow view. I am not necessarily suggesting that they were wrong, but they had a somewhat narrow view and could not see the broader implications of what they were doing. And it was not six months before they were back changing it. I urge upon Hon. Members, particularly those who sit on the committee, to keep this in mind as they go through the processes of deciding what ought to be and what ought not to be allowed within the parliamentary process here.
I see Mr. Speaker indicating that I do not have much more time remaining. I happen to know that the Hon. Member for Humboldt-Lake Centre will ask me a question, which will permit me to complete my remarks.

Mr. Speaker, I was listening to what the Hon. Member said about how the process works. His concern reflects very much the concerns which I felt as I went as a first-time participant to a meeting of the organizing committee for the Standing Committee on Health, Welfare and Social Affairs. I should like the House to understand what a sense of sadness I felt as a first-time participant when I realized I was both a participant and a witness to an absolute mockery of the democratic process.
There is a statement indicating that a democracy is measured by the way it treats its minorities. I sincerely hope that the Government will take into consideration the question of whether in this instance the minorities are the judge of how the Government will handle its legislation.
Here in what I have been calling, as I watch it unfold, the theatre of the absurd, I thought that was one thing and that it was a good public show. However, I was really anxious to participate in what I consider to be real democracy at work and the real role and responsibility of government. I was looking forward to meeting my colleagues in a spirit of collegi-ality and to addressing pressing issues in today's society with a sense of fairness and equity, with the knowledge that justice would be heard and that we would be together acting in the best interests of all Canadians. It is a sad day when I stand here to say that I was dreadfully disappointed. I sincerely hope the matter will see some redress from the Leader across the way. I believe it was Talleyrand who said that it is not a crime, it is just a mistake. I sincerely hope he looks at this as a genuine mistake, because I did not find it a farce and I would like very much to see the whole situation rectified.

Mr. Speaker, the Hon. Member for Mount Royal (Mrs. Finestone) has said very elegantly and eloquently what I frankly felt about it. I think it posed a problem. There is no doubt about that. I said that at the beginning of my comments. However, I would suggest to her, through the Chair, that not all the real work of Parliament is done in committees. I want to make that point, which I hope is important. Some of the real work of Parliament is done in committees, but not all of it. It is in this Chamber that Members have an opportunity to discuss en masse their concerns. I do not want ever to shift the focus of responsibility so totally from the Chamber of the House of Commons to the committee system. The committee system is good, and if allowed to work well-and I hope it will be after this misunderstanding is corrected-it will serve the public in the way it was intended. I believe the Chamber itself is an important part of the democratic political process and must be maintained with opportunity.
I should like to add one comment, which I know the Hon. Member is interested in hearing although she did not raise it directly. I am concerned about another aspect of Members' work, that is, operations within the constituencies. It has been clear to me over the course of what is nearly the last five years that the work-load of Members in their constituencies has risen dramatically. The requirements of Members to find ways to solve sometimes difficult and sometimes not so difficult

problems have grown by leaps and bounds. As the committee deliberates I would ask it to look at the problems now confronting those who work on our behalf in our constituencies. I know the committee intends to look at the problems of those working on our behalf on Parliament Hill, but I beg it to spend some time looking seriously at the problems in constituencies to know how we can better serve our constituents and ease the work-load of constituency assistants.
I never cease to be amazed that my constituency assistant stays in that job. It has to be the most onerous of tasks. It is heart-rending. It requires tremendous physical, mental and emotional capacity. It is paid pitifully. As well, that single individual, particularly in urban areas, is required to work countless extra hours without any additional help. The chairman of the committee in his early deliberations should ask it to look at this situation which has been allowed to arise to see if there is a way to give assistance to the assistants so that we do not overburden very dedicated individuals who are underpaid and overworked and who are the front-line troops in the ongoing service of constituencies. They are the ones who five, six and seven days a week, ten twelve and fourteen hours per day, are meeting and dealing with the problems face to face. While we may have some oversight responsibility in many of them, we do not have to see the agony as much as constituency assistants do. I ask the chairman to consider that too.

speechtext:
I might be laughing right now, but I can assure Members opposite that what happened to me this morning in the Standing Committee on Health and Welfare was no laughing matter. As a matter of fact, it struck at me. Most Members of this House realize that I rarely lose my temper. If I am not mistaken, this was the first time in my five years in Parliament that I have ever lost my temper in committee. I felt that my rights had been abused so badly by the majority presence of the Conservative Members of Parliament on that committee that I had no recourse but to stomp out of the committee.
I mentioned before that there was a time when you did not have to become a procedural expert. After the happenings of yesterday and today in various committees other than the Health and Welfare Committee, everybody on the Opposition side will have to become well versed in the rules and procedures of this House. This is mainly because there seems to be a concerted attempt being made by the Conservative Government.
I respect the attitude that the Government House Leader has always taken toward this House. I am not sure that it was a directive issued by him. Certainly I suspect that the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr. Nielsen), as in fact is evident, issued directives to each of the committee chairmen to remove one of the essential rights that we have always had in committee, that when evidence was heard there had to be a member of the opposition. Parties present to preserve the right of democracy.
I want to read something because since this morning I understand that, from a procedural standpoint I have been on very weak ground. The Standing Orders do not indicate that there is any rule that would require the presence of an opposition member when evidence is to be heard. I want to have placed on the record the fact that at this morning's committee meeting, I read into the record the same motion that was presented to that committee in 1980 when it was
being formed. In that motion the then government recognized the requirement that a person form the Official Opposition needs to be present in order to hear evidence. This morning I did not even ask for the right that the Official Opposition be present. I just asked for the right that a member of the Opposition be present for the hearing of evidence. The majority Conservative Government, for whatever reasons or whatever paranoia, decided on a unanimous vote of the committee to reverse that long-standing tradition in this House.
I want to read something into the record that was aid by a former Member of this House, Mr. Stanley Knowles, who now sits at the Table. Here is what he said about the role of an Opposition:
It is the opposition's right to insist at all times on the full protection of the rules of debate. The government is entitled to that same protection, but in addition it has its majority with which to establish its will.
A majority of 211 seats is a pretty powerful weapon. It is powerful enough in its own merit not to go the added step of removing the rights of a minority, namely, those of the Official Opposition. He went on:
The opposition has only the rules for its protection, hence the authorities on parliamentary procedure emphasize the great importance to the opposition of the only protection it has, the protection of the rules.
I want to talk a bit about those rules. I have learned a lot in the last three and a half hours. I went to the Library and picked up a book by Erskine May. This should be informative to the newer Members of Parliament, and it was an interesting exercise for me today. I wanted to find out exactly how these rules and regulations come about that dictate the manner in which we operate this Parliament. Here is what Erskine May had to say about the parliamentary rules. A lot of it is written and even more is what is called unwritten procedure. I quote from page 209:
On its smaller scale, the study of English parliamentary procedure presents the same difficulty as the study of English law in that its rules are not covered by any comprehensive and authoritative code. It is true that in both Houses one portion of procedure-private business, which is concerned with local and personal legislation-
On the whole, a great many of the procedures which dictate the conduct of Members of Parliament, whether here in the House of Commons or in committee, are based on what is called unwritten procedure. Let me read into the record a passage from page 215 of that same book. This passage deals with the historical relation between practice and the Standing Orders. It reads as follows:
It cannot be denied that there is a marked contrast in spirit between the historical practice of the House of Commons and its modern standing orders. That practice dates from a time when the Commons regarded themselves as in opposition to the Crown and the executive, and their forms and rules were largely devised to delay and temporise.
It goes on to indicate that over the years, the executive has tended to enhance its role in the parliamentary process and therefore it became even more important that the rules and procedures be adapted so that we as Members of Parliament could ensure that the rights and the voices of minority groups could be heard in Parliament.
November 22, 1984

I would like to recount to Hon. Members opposite something that was said by a man for whom I had a great deal of respect in the last Parliament, a man who passed away. He was the Hon. Member for Nepean-Carleton, the Hon. Walter Baker. When he was the President of the Privy Council and Leader of the Government in the House, he put forward in November 1979 a position paper entitled The Reform of Parliament. About the committee structure, he said that the following proposals were intended to give committees some investigative initiative, provide more staff resources and stabilize memberships by reducing them. A mild restraint was placed on the process of initiating investigations to prevent a multiplicity of studies at any one time.
He went on to say that it should be noted that the committees' role is expanded to improve the accountability of Government-that was one concept that he had in mind-and not to give committees executive functions. He went on to indicate that committees may hold serious investigations that are against the will of the Government. This is not at present possible.
How can a Party, which, some five short years ago, had in its midst a man with that kind of vision of what parliamentary procedures should be all about, reverse itself completely in the last two days and, through its parliamentary majority, impose its will upon the Opposition in Parliament? I might want to remind Hon. Members that the Opposition numbers only 70 Members versus 211 government members. If we are looking at parliamentary reform, surely some of the first things that should be looked at are changes to the Standing Orders that would prevent the abuse of my rights as a parliamentarian, such as the abuse which occurred to me in committee today.
The Government House Leader indicated earlier today in response to a question that I asked of him that he would be willing to investigate this matter. I do not think an investigation will be enough. What will be required is a complete reversal of the passage of those motions which were passed not only in the standing committee which I represent this morning but in all standing committees, with one exception. I understand that one committee bucked the trend today at 3.30 p.m., probably as a result of the pressures put on its committee chairman and the cries of outrage that have been heard since the meetings at 9.30 this morning. I understand that this afternoon, the Employment and Immigration Committee refused to pass a motion which would have allowed the committee to sit without representation from opposition Parties. I think the Member of Parliament from Calgary deserves credit for having bucked the directive of the Hon. Member for Yukon by allowing Members of the Opposition at least the privilege of being heard.
I would like to return to the government position paper written in 1979 by the then President of the Privy Council. He said therein that a mild restraint would be placed on these reforms by putting a caveat limiting the number of committees that could be struck at any one time. That the motion was put that committees could hear evidence without the presence of an opposition member means in essence that every one of those
Parliamentary Reform
committees can now strike up a committee of four members of the Conservative Party to travel across the country.
In essence, we have created a system in which abuse is now possible. There could be a whole series of Conservative task forces travelling across the country hearing evidence without any representation by a member of an opposition Party. I am not suggesting that the Government would be crazy enough to try that. The point is that we should never allow motions to be placed on the minutes of committees that would allow that to happen.
Surely, one of the primary functions that will be required of you, Mr. Speaker, and of others in the chair, will be to protect the minority rights in this Parliament. The Chair surely understands that when there is a massive majority of 211 government Members of Parliament facing a puny Opposition of only 70 Members, it will be required that the 70 of us spend most of our time in this House, or at best 200 yards from this House, working and doing the job that an Official Opposition member should be doing in committee. If this motion is allowed to stand, I think we will see an abuse of the system by the majority Government. There will be very little opportunity, I can assure you, for members of the Liberal Party to travel outside of Ottawa to hear evidence.
I would also suggest, Mr. Speaker, that I know that no one Government has a monopoly on its members. The Hon. Member from British Columbia had the pleasure of being the vice-chairman of one of our task forces. When we were a majority Government, there were times when we invited members of the Opposition not only to be there to hear evidence but to be vice-chairmen of some of these committees. During this morning's procedure, I entertained no thought of suggesting that one of us might want to be a vice-chairman of a standing committee. I knew, simply by seeing the gleam in the eyes of government members caused by what they were about to do to me, that there was no sense in even advocating the elevation of an opposition member to the position of vice-chairman of a committee.
The Hon. Member for St. John's East has the respect of Members of Parliament on all sides of the House. I would hope that one of the things he would do as Chairman of this committee is to ensure in even more detail the right of the minority in Parliament to establish itself. I expect the Hon. Member to do that.
As I mentioned earlier, I have no intention of taking up the full 20 minutes. However, I hope that the Government House Leader, and if not the Government House Leader then the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney), will issue a directive to each one of those committee chairmen to reverse the decisions that were made today and return to the opposition Parties the right to be present when evidence is heard.
In an esoteric sense, this is not a prime concern of only the Official Opposition. I am not concerned only because 1 am worried about what that decision means to the Liberal Party or to the New Democratic Party. My concern is for the groups that will appear before our committees.

November 22, 1984
Parliamentary Reform
Let me use a very absurd example. I notice that the Hon. Minister of National Health and Welfare (Mr. Epp) has left the House. However, let us assume that the Government is following some of the directions that were outlined in the economic statement made by the Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson). Let us assume that the Government desired to make cut-backs to the social service programs of the country. As a result of that, let us say that a committee was empowered to hear evidence. It is quite possible that some poor person who would be adversely affected by those kinds of cuts would come before the committee, and because the rule states that no member of the Opposition need be present to hear the evidence, find himself being questioned by only four Conservative Members of Parliament, none of whom would solicit viewpoints from him that would tend to embarrass the government position. That is the abuse that becomes possible when motions are passed like the one that was passed in the committees this morning.
This is not going to go away, Mr. Speaker. I do not know how long it will take, but that motion must be rescinded and reversed.
