Hon. Warren Allmand (Notre-Dame-de-Grace-Lachine
East): Mr. Speaker, I attended the organization meeting this morning of the Standing Committee on Indian Affairs and Northern Development. I must say that after attending that meeting I was infuriated. It was my intention to come here this afternoon and let this House know how I felt about what took place there. I calmed down this afternoon after attending the meeting of the Standing Committee on Labour, Manpower and Immigration because in that committee, after some discussion, the Conservative members were willing to put forward a motion that, for purposes of hearing evidence, there need only be three members of the committee present, two from the government side and one from the opposition side. The fear of the Hon. House Leader, therefore, that three or four members of the Opposition could meet without the Government was not well-founded. The proposal which was accepted was one, by the way, which we tried to make in the Standing Committee on Indian Affairs and Northern Development this morning. We tried to amend the motion which was put forward by the Parliamentary Secretary. We felt that out of four members of the committee, at least one member should be from the Opposition. That was voted down and the motion was rammed through to the effect that only the chairman or vice-chairman, with four members, need be present on the committee, and no opposition member had to be present.
With the exception of what happened in the Standing Committee on Labour, Manpower and Immigration, all the motions in all the committees yesterday and today were handled in the same way. In every case amendments allowing opposition members to play some role in the quorum were refused. I was particularly upset with the Standing Committee on Indian Affairs and Northern Development because that is a committee which, over the last five or six years, has operated in a very non-partisan way. As a matter of fact, it has been an innovative committee, one which has served as a model for parliamentary reform in this House. It was the first committee to invite ex officio members to work with it in the Indian

November 22, 1984
Parliamentary Reform
self-government study. It was a committee in the last Parliament where we used to work together.
In answer to some of the points which were raised by Hon. Members opposite, in the last Parliament, when the Liberals had the majority and were asked to give place to the Opposition in the quorum, we did so. We could have rammed through motions as the Government did this morning and yesterday, but we did not do so. We respected the rights of the Opposition. As a matter of fact, in the Standing Committee on Indian Affairs and Northern Development in the last Parliament, the Official Opposition had to be represented. That was accepted by the Liberal majority of that committee. The Official Opposition had to be represented, not just the New Democratic Party or any other opposition Party. In the Standing Committee on Indian Affairs and Northern Development in the last Parliament we met together and drafted a report condemning the then Minister of Indian and Northern Affairs on his handling of the James Bay situation. Committee members both from the Government and the Opposition, after listening to evidence and discussing it among themselves, drafted a report taking to task a Minister of the Crown, even though he was a member of the Government. The same thing was done with respect to the Conne River incident, the fact that the Conne River Indians had not been granted status after years of lobbying to that effect.
What has taken place in most of the committees up to this time, with the exception of the Standing Committee on Labour, Manpower and Immigration, is unacceptable. It is unaccetable that the Government with its great majority would crush the rights of the Opposition.
I would like to point out to the Hon. House Leader that there is another situation where this is happening as well. Perhaps, the Hon. House Leader is not aware of it. I do not know if anyone has raised the matter thus far in the debate. In the motion to set up this task force on parliamentary reform, there is no provision for minority reports. I can recall very well when we set up the task forces in the last Parliament-and I was Chairman of the Task Force On Employment Opportunities for the 80s-the Opposition insisted that written into the reference should be the right to have minority reports included in the majority report, printed, and given as much space as was necessary to express its views. That right is not included in this motion today, and I do not know why it is not included.

It could be an oversight and I would hope, because of this debate, that provision will be made, as was made on several occasions on task forces in the last Parliament, for minority reports to be printed in the volume setting forth the full report. With respect to the Task Force on Employment Opportunities for the 80s, two Conservative opposition members filed minority reports on three or four recommendations and the New Democratic Party Filed them on other recommendations. They were allowed to write those reports themselves. The same thing was done on several other
task forces, and I cannot see why anyone would be opposed to that being done now.
I know that with respect to standing committees, minority reports are not allowed. However, in task forces during the last Parliament this had been allowed, and I would hope that some change could be made to permit minority reports, because we are dealing with a wide range of matters.
With respect to reform of the House, the Speech from the Throne said that Members of the House of Commons will be asked to approve the appointment of a parliamentary task force on reform of the House. The central focus of this task force would be the enhancement of the role of the private Member. From that perspective, the task force will examine and make recommendations concerning the powers, practices, organization and resources of the House of Commons. I listened to the speech of the Hon. House Leader and his intentions are fine, but Government Members are doing exactly the opposite in committees. They are reducing the rights of private Members. They are doing the very opposite to what was stated would be done in the Speech from the Throne and in the resolution which was put before us today.
The Hon. House Leader, for whom I have a great deal of respect, said that no order came down from him or elsewhere. However, it is very odd that in every committee, the Parliamentary Secretary put forward motions which deliberately excluded opposition members in the formation of a quorum. As my colleague, the Hon. Member for Sudbury (Mr. Frith), pointed out, this would allow these task forces to go on the road without any opposition members. It is going to be difficult for Hon. Members on this side if government members decide, because of their majority, to travel throughout the country, or throughout the world, as this motion would allow them to do. We have no way of preventing that because Hon. Members opposite have the majority. What we, in fact, will see are Conservative task forces travelling throughout the country and throughout the world-probably throughout the country because that is better politics-but not at their own expense. The Conservatives had some very good task forces during the last Parliament, for instance, the task force on national revenue which examined tax problems. There was as well an earlier task force on some other matters. That is fine. It was financed by that Party. However, to manipulate the orders of the House and the rules of the committees so that that can be done flies completely in the face of what is stated here today and what was stated in the Speech from the Throne.
I was with the Hon. Member for St. John's East (Mr. McGrath) on a committee on reform. We worked very intensely. We heard a lot of witnesses and put out ten reports. Seven of those were substantive reports and dealt with every item which is in this motion from (a) to (g) except for item (e). Item (e) states that the task force should study:
the funding, facilities and staff support services made available to Members of the House of Commons;
We did not study that. But we did study item (a), namely, the permanent and provisional Standing Orders. Of course, we
November 22, 1984

studied them intensely. Item (b), the role of the private Member in the House of Commons, was dealt with in reports Nos. 3 and 10. Item (c) concerning the accountability of Ministers to the House of Commons was dealt with at great length in report No. 7. Item (d) regarding the legislative process was dealt with in report No. 3. Item (0 on the administration and management of the House of Commons was dealt with in report No. 9. Item (g) reads:
the procedures and powers of Committees of the House of Commons and the role and the use of parliamentary task forces;
That item was dealt with in reports Nos. 3, 5 and 6 of the last special committee. Therefore, there is a lot which has already been dealt with. Ten members of the present Conservative caucus worked with that special committee at one time or another, and those Hon. Members are still sitting in this House. Three members of that special committee are now Ministers: the Government House Leader, the Minister of National Health and Welfare (Mr. Epp), and I believe the Minister of State responsible for the Wheat Board (Mr. Mayer). The Hon. Member for St. John's East was on the committee, and most of our reports were unanimous.

But it was a good balance.
Members of this House and the public will know that most of the things in the third report, which was the first substantive report, are now part of the provisional standing orders, and we are dealing with them right now. It dealt with such things as the parliamentary timetable, the length of speeches, the fact we now have a 20-minute speech with a 10-minute period for questions and comments. It dealt with the committee system, the fact that reports tabled under Acts of Parliament are automatically referred to committee, not by special order. It referred to Private Members' Business and so on. All this was done by agreement among the Parties at that time, and today those recommendations are in effect, but on a provisional basis.
Parliamentary Reform
Of the other reports that we agreed on unanimously, the fourth report dealt with the election of the Speaker, but it was not followed. I do not say that in any way to criticize any of the Speakers of this House, but the fact was that we agreed unanimously on a new way of electing the Speaker, but it was not carried through.
The fifth and sixth reports deal with committees and their power. Nothing in those reports has been implemented.
The seventh report deals with the financial control of the Government by Members of Parliament. A lot of time was spent on that report and a lot of credit is due to two former Members of this House, Ron Huntington from Capilano and Claude Andre Lachance from Montreal. Both of them did a lot of very good work which led to that report.
The ninth report dealt with the Commissioners for Internal Economy and it attempted to give more power to Members of Parliament, including the Opposition, in controlling matters which affect all Members of this House, such as offices, secretaries and support services. Again that report was ignored by the Government when it appointed the Commissioners for Internal Economy in the same way as has always been done. I realize that the law says that the Commissioners for Internal Economy must be Privy Counsellors, but it does not say that all those Privy Counsellors have to be on the government side of the House.
The tenth report dealt with statements by Ministers, questions of confidence in the Government, how to deal with Ways and Means motions, what happens when we have votes on Friday, the recognition of Members in the House, Private Members' Business, and a new and more effective way of voting.
In a period of time of over one year that committee dealt with nearly every item which is going to be dealt with here.
It seems to me that the Government could show its good faith with respect to reform of Parliament if the Government House Leader were to meet with the House Leaders of the other Parties and discuss with them how to implement immediately some of those recommendations that had been unanimously agreed to. If the Government did that and did not carry on the kind of skulduggery we saw in the committees this morning, then we in the Opposition and maybe other private Members would be able to say that the Government is serious, that it is acting in good faith and wants to do something about the reform of Parliament. But we become a bit dubious when there is no attempt to implement the recommendations made unanimously in the last Parliament by that special committee. Then we have the sort of thing that went on today. I also point to the fact that in the resolution before us there is no provision for minority reports.
It is my firm belief, Mr. Speaker, that we will not see drastic reform in this House until we do something about the question of confidence. We discussed this at great length in the last Parliament. The fact that any vote can be considered a vote of confidence inhibits private Members in committee and in the House from putting forward amendments to criticize, even in a

November 22, 1984
Parliamentary Reform
constructive way, because they feel that to vote against their own Party when in government, or to be in opposition with their own Party, might lead to a question of confidence which would defeat the Government and cause an election. That is hard to imagine in the present circumstances, but that parliamentary tradition affects the House in that way. In the tenth report, I believe, we made a recommendation that on Opposition Days, when a vote is attached to an opposition motion, it should not be considered a confidence vote unless it is expressly set out in the motion. If the motion drafted by the Opposition said that the House expresses a lack of confidence in the Government because of whatever, then it would be considered a want of confidence motion. But if it does not do that, then every motion put forward for a vote on an Opposition Day should simply be dealt with on its own merits.
Last year we had a motion put forward by the New Democratic Party to reject testing of Cruise missiles. There was nothing in its motion that expressed lack of confidence in the Government, but the NDP wanted the House to express itself on that very important point. At that time, six Members on the Government side abstained altogether because they were against the testing of Cruise missiles, but they said they did not want to vote with the opposition motion because they did not want to precipitate an election. They were caught in the dilemma of being in agreement with the opposition motion but they did not want to precipitate an election. I personally voted with the Opposition because I thought the question was serious, and in any case I did not think the Government would call an election on that.
I think the new Members of the House, especially those on the government side, will find as they work in these committees that there will be times when, after listening to the evidence, they will want to amend the Bill. They will feel deep inside that that is what should be done. But unless we can change the rules that will allow them to do that without expressing a lack of confidence in their own government, they will not do it. I can understand that this large number of Conservative members would prefer their own Government to any other government, but they may differ with the Government on certain points from time to time. They should have the right to vote against those Bills or amend them without expressing lack of confidence in the Government. Until we do something about that, Mr. Speaker, I think we will not change radically what happens in this House.
If committees are going to be meaningful, we have to give them more support services. If you are going to be a counterbalance to the great power the Government has with large Departments, advisers and counsellors and so on, if you are going to take issue with some of the proposals put to you, you need at least some expertise on economic and social matters, statistics and so on, to help you question and put forward alternatives. I think that is extremely important and goes to the very base of parliamentary reform.
I came to this House today originally to oppose this motion with all the force I had. I am a bit encouraged by the statement made just a few moments ago by the House Leader
that he is willing to reconsider what was done in some of the committees today and correct it. If that is the case, I think he shows good faith. We will be waiting for him to act on that. I would also ask if he would try to make provision for minority reports in this task force and other task forces that will be set up. That is what was done in the last Parliament and it was done at the request of members of his Party. They insisted on it and the Government agreed to it. It was agreed upon through consultations.
Let us have reform of Parliament. It is essential. Let us have it in a way in which all Members of the House participate, even those of us in the Opposition. Give us a chance to participate too. Many of us have something to put forward.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to make a comment. The Hon. Member expressed concern that the reference contained no provision for a minority report. The Hon. Member knows full well that if this task force is to succeed, it must have a unanimous report. That is precisely why no provision was made for a minority report in the last reference setting up the special committee. There is nothing to stop Hon. Members from bringing in a minority report if there is a very serious difference of opinion on any single aspect of any single report of the committee.
Second, the Hon. It made no reference whatsoever to parliamentary task forces being empowered to bring in minority reports. I refer the Hon. Member to that recommendation. It refers to membership and the usefulness of the task forces. It recommends that they be an ongoing part of Parliament. However, it makes no reference whatsoever to minority reports.
I agree with the Hon. Member on the outstanding reports of the special committee. There are six of those and one which merely deals with unsubstantive changes in one of the previous reports. No matter how wise our House Leaders are, the fact is that we have 282 Members of Parliament, and the reason that we have Parliament is that government, the Cabinet, must submit its proposals to Parliament. If Parliament works properly, there should be discussion within Parliament about how to improve what has been put forward by the wise people in Cabinet and, in this case, the wise House Leaders.
Let me explain what probably happened. We have a number of Members, including our House Leader, who were Cabinet Ministers for a long time. The Hon. Member will find out that when you are a Cabinet member for a long time, you lose touch with the ordinary day-to-day happenings in parliamentary committees and in the House. Mr. Speaker, I rise to discuss the motion to set up a special committee on
House of Commons reform. It is a committee that our caucus and our House Leader have discussed and approved. We gave that approval on the basis of consensus and in a spirit of co-operation. I believe those were the guidelines set out at the opening of Parliament. They are very important principles to keep in mind in order for the House to function in its traditional way.
I believe that this motion would have passed in a matter of minutes had we not had the unfortunate experience in the committees yesterday and today. That spirit of consensus and co-operation was dashed when the Government used its very large majority in an attempt to change a parliamentary tradition around the world that recognizes minority rights whether they be those of the Opposition in Parliament or of groups outside of Parliament. That right has been a longstanding tradition of parliamentary practice.
That tradition was ignored and trampled on in the various committees in the past two days and has sent a very important signal to members of the opposition Parties. I believe it has set the tone, a very unfortunate tone, for future practice in the House.
Yesterday, when I left the committee which I attended, I discovered there was a breach of tradition. I thought it was an isolated case and recognized that, it being an agricultural committee, perhaps it had been overlooked somewhat. The government members of that committee had not attended committees in previous Parliaments and perhaps could be forgiven for not understanding the necessity of following the unwritten rules, procedures and traditions of parliamentary practice. That was my feeling when I left that committee. I was giving it the benefit of the doubt.
I was trying to maintain that sense of spirit and co-operation that is so necessary to the functioning of this place. However, after consulting with my colleagues from other committees I found that the practice in those committees was precisely the same. There was no recognition of the need for both sides of the House to be represented in minimum quorums for hearing of evidence. There was no agreement or recognition by the government side that both sides should be represented when major decisions are to be made with a quorum. There was no recognition of continuing that longstanding practice in the steering committees.
In our committee, the Chairman or the government members did not even concede that there was a recognized need for a notice to be given before a meeting is held. The Chairman informed us that all meetings would be at the call of the Chair, with no time set for an advanced notice of meetings.
There is really no guarantee of the rights of the minorities in the House, even to know when a meeting would be held. It leaves no chance for parliamentary traditions and practices to be recognized.
I think that is the reason for the Government's problem. We are having second thoughts about renewing a committee that will study parliamentary practice. A previous committee did a very good job in studying this issue, and some of its recommen-

November 22, 1984
dations have been acted upon. In fact, this particular debate is being conducted as a result of the implementation of some of those recommendations. We cannot feel comfortable about approving the establishment of such a committee when there has been such a recent and unfortunate indication from the Government about its thoughts on minorities and opposition Parties. It leaves us suspicious about hidden agendas. It leaves us insecure about what the Government's intentions are.
Until such time as the Government gives a clear indication that it has made a mistake with respect to these committees, I do no think it would be appropriate for us, in the interest of parliamentary tradition and practice, to proceed with a review of parliamentary practice. Until the Government rethinks its attitude with regard the parliamentary process, I think we would be loath to go into any further negotiations at this point in time.

Mr. Speaker, the issue I raised with the Minister of State for Finance (Mrs. McDougall) on November 19 dealt with the appointment or alleged appointment-in fact there really was no committee- by the former Minister of State for Finance of a committee which was to deal with problems besetting the entire financial intermediary community.
Briefly it can be said that there are four pillars of financial intermediaries, or however one may want to describe them- banks, trust companies, security dealers and insurance companies. I think we should include the credit unions. That would be at least five pillars. Some people have suggested that perhaps lawyers, notaries and others dealing with assisting people in financing might also be included.
The problem has been that these various companies and organizations involved in the financial community are attempting and have been attempting over a period of time to take over the business of each other. For example-and I only use this as an example-the Royal Bank of Canada was heavily involved in automobile leasing. The Bank Act was altered and automobile leasing was specifically excluded from banks. Now the Royal Bank of Canada is involved in a program where it buys back automobiles. It leads a person money and at the end of the term the car can be sold to the Royal Bank to satisfy the loan balance. It is a form of leasing by the back door.
Apparently it was also involved, according to the latest release, in organizing equity financing in Canada for those who might want to invest in Canada. It is in the financial security business. It operates out of the Cayman Islands. That is another activity. We have the banks and security dealers taking money on deposit and selling treasury bills and securities of all kinds. We have insurance companies selling annuities for one year. Imagine a one year annuity. It is really a rolling over of a one year promissory note or guaranteed investment certificate.
We have a problem where the whole discipline in the financial market has gone. Organizations under one ruse or another are able to go beyond what was originally deemed the scope of their powers. We have developing the concept of a financial supermarket. This whole matter must be addressed by Parliament and must be addressed as soon as possible.
The former government knew this. Rather than have Parliament address the matter, the former minister appointed a little select committee. That select committee was supposed to be a task force. He went around the country telling people that he

I and other members of our party called on the then Minister of State for Finance and Minister of Finance to set up a parliamentary committee to inquire, study the matter and report to Parliament so that laws and statutes could be passed to amend the current law with respect to financial intermediaries.
1 say again today to the current Minister that this group, which is now winding up its activities, should be dismissed. It was an interesting group, but it did not accomplish anything. It cannot accomplish anything. The matter should be immediately referred to the Standing Committee on Finance, Trade and Economic Affairs or a task force set up, if that is the pleasure of the Government, to study this issue so that we can come to grips with it.
Financial intermediaries are very important in the development of Canada. Our laws with respect to them have to be amended. They must be brought up to date. If not, our country will suffer. It will be more difficult to move money from one investment activity to another. It must be dealt with as soon as possible. I hope this Parliament will come to grips with that issue.

Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to rise in the House to answer this question. I also wish to thank the men and women of the riding of St. Paul's and the Right Hon. Prime Minister (Mr. Mul-roney) for having given me this honour.

No one is more aware of the confusion in the financial intermediary system than I am. I have spent 20 years of my life working the financial sector. In fact, I worked for three of the four or five pillars, depending on how one defines them. I am also, as all of us are, a consumer of financial services.
In response to my colleague's question, there is indeed a private sector Advisory Committee on Financial Institutions. It is probably not constitued as he would have constituted it, and probably not as I would have either, but let me just give some history of this committee.
It is chaired by William Dimma, the President of A. E. LePage, and is known as the Dimma committee. Its composition is mainly of senior executives from major private financial corporations with some consumer and academic representations. It was formed in January 1984 by the previous government. Its purpose was to provide the then Minister with a private-sector perspective on the structural changes in the industry, many of which were outlined by my colleague in his question. The Dimma Committee was also to comment on the Finance Department's working papers on the modernization of the legislation for financial institutions.
On behalf of the Government, I decided to allow the committee to convene for one more meeting. I believe it is important to allow the committee to continue to study the working papers of the Department of Finance and, more importantly, I believe it is important to proceed with legislation in this important area as rapidly as possible, and in that process to present papers to the House.
I will be furthering the consultation process in this important area in a very specific way to ensure that the harmonization of financial institutions legislation is complete. This consultation will be carried out in a very specific and limited time frame.
As the House knows, our Party had launched the most comprehensive consultative process of any Government in our history. With no disrespect to members of the Dimma Committee who are persons of distinction, I agree with my hon. colleague that this committee is a good example of the consultation process gone wrong. The financial institutions in our country have been in need of revised legislation for many years. Indeed, the Trust Companies Act and the Loan Companies Act have not been substantially revised since the early part of the century.
Instead of action, the industry leaders were given, as my colleague has suggested, a series of dinners and asked to comment on papers produced by the Department. I intend to speed up the process that my hon. colleague has outlined by way of better consultation and by proceeding to legislation.

subtopic: EMPLOYMENT-YOUTH TRAINING OPTION PROGRAM. (B) GOVERNMENT'S POSITION

speechtext:
Hon. Warren Allmand (Notre-Dame-de-Grace-Lachine
East): Mr. Speaker, on Wednesday, November 7, I asked the Minister of Employment and Immigration (Miss MacDonald) how she justified the cancellation of the First Chance Program which was implemented to train and employ young people by replacing it with the Youth Training Option Program. First Chance was ready to begin on October 1. It would have provided $100 million in its first year to help young people train on the job, and it would have provided $1 billion per year over a five-year period. In 1985, it would have provided for 100,000 trainees.
November 22, 1984

I was extremely supportive of that program since it fell in line with certain recommendations made in the report of the Task Force on Employment Opportunities for the 80s, a report made by a task force of which I was chairman in 1980 and 1981. By the way, those recommendations were given unanimous support by all members of the task force.
The Minister cancelled First Chance and replaced it with the Youth Training Option Program, a similar but more limited program. Instead of providing $100 million in its First year, the Minister received only $27 million to carry out that program. Instead of it being a permanent program, it was to be a pilot project. This has happened despite all the rhetoric and promises made during the election campaign with respect to training and employment.
The Minister explained to me that she had an obligation to consult with provinces, business and labour. My answer to that is twofold, Mr. Speaker. First, the fact that the Minister had to withdraw the First Chance Program and put in place a pilot project and consult further was an admission that she and the Government had no plans or blueprints for training when they made these promises during the election campaign. They were going to start from scratch and develop a program through consultation.
Second, why was it necessary to consult all over again as if nothing had been done before? I would like to point out that since 1980 there have been approximately 10 task forces and commissions dealing with this very subject, eight of which have reported. I can refer to some of them.
There was the Task Force on Employment Opportunities for the 80s, the Dodge Commission Report, a Report called In the Chips which dealt with employment in the micro-electronics industry, two reports by the Economic Council of Canada on this subject, the Commission for Part-time Work, the Commission for Paid Educational Leave, the Major Projects Task Force, the Task Force on Employment Outreach Programs and the Michelle Jean Report from Quebec. Those reports were presented in the last five years and were all on the same subject. They involved much consultation with all the groups the Minister indicates she will consult.
In addition, the Conservative Party had its own task force in 1983-84 under the chairmanship of the Hon. Member for Calgary West (Mr. Hawkes). That task force consulted broadly and published a report which included recommendations with respect to training on the job.
Now is the time for action with respect to training on the job and employment programs for young people. It is not a time for further study. I strongly urge the Government to move ahead and provide hope to young people who are unemployed and need training. It should be done now, and we should not have to wait for further studies and consultation.
[ Translation]

speakeroldname: Mr. Jean-Guy Hudon (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Employment and Immigration
subtopic: EMPLOYMENT-YOUTH TRAINING OPTION PROGRAM. (B) GOVERNMENT'S POSITION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on behalf
Adjournment Debate
of the Minister of Employment and Immigration (Miss MacDonald), I am pleased to explain to the Hon. Member why this government has introduced the $27 million Youth Training Option Program. This government has said on many occasions that it was committed to do something about the tragic lot of unemployed youths. The Youth Training Option is a new approach to the problem. The Hon. Member claims that this approach has been examined and tried many times. That is not true. A similar program is in force in the United Kingdom and has proved to be a resounding success. The Youth Training Option is similar to the British program, but the fact is that the idea has never been implemented in Canada.
When the Minister announced the program, she said that it was a pilot project. We would rather not spend too much of the taxpayers' money on a program which has yet to be tested. I might remind the Hon. Member that, last May, the previous government had announced a $30 million experimental program called Youth Training Option. In any case, during the election campaign that experimental program was suddenly replaced by another $1 billion program called First Chance, despite the fact that the original Youth Training Option never did get off the ground and that there were no consultations with the provinces.
As the previous government knew very well, the $1 billion was never made available. No one knew how that $1 billion would be financed in 1985-86. Our government would rather not follow that example. The Minister will meet with her provincial colleagues and consult them to make sure that any federal program aimed at reducing youth unemployment meshes with any proposed or existing provincial initiative. Businesses and unions will also be consulted so as to ensure their support and cooperation. The only way to find effective solutions to fight against youth unemployment is to work with all sectors of the Canadian economy.
The Youth Training Option will be launched immediately to provide training and practical work experience for 3,000 or 4,000 young Canadians. With the cooperation of the provinces, businesses and unions, we will be able to help more young men and women. We do not want to act irresponsibly nor promise something we as a government cannot deliver. Should we find out that the program does work, and once we know the provinces, businesses and unions agree, we will make a huge joint effort which will undoubtedly meet the requirements of the Canadian labour market and those of young Canadians.
Now, in answer to the Hon. Member who asked: Why consult? If we are to set up a joint and coherent program with the provinces, other federal agencies, municipalities, unions and what have you, consultation has to be the order of the day. In that respect, I must say that the previous government was not much in favour of consultation.

November 22, 1984
Adjournment Debate

subtopic: UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE-NEWFOUNDLAND FISHERMEN- REQUEST FOR ASSISTANCE
UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE-NEWFOUNDLAND FISHERMEN- REQUEST FOR ASSISTANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, 1 am so pleased to keep hearing from government Members that the Government will have consultations. It has bothered me sometimes in listening to recent answers given by Cabinet Ministers in the House to learn that exactly the opposite is true. Exactly the opposite is true in the worst way imaginable.
I realize it is difficult for Ministers to know what the facts are, because they have a lot of work to do and they have to prepare for Question Period. However, we have reached the point in the House where we are dealing with primary producers who are forced to turn to welfare to live and who cannot feed their families, yet the Minister stands in this House, as she did on November 13, and says the following:
It is my understanding that in the last few weeks there have been sufficient fishing opportunities so as to permit fisher people to qualify for the ten weeks that would allow them to collect unemployment insurance benefits.
While the Minister was saying that, Mr. Speaker, she had on her desk a recommendation from the Federal Department of Fisheries with respect to instituting a special program so that fishermen could qualify for unemployment insurance benefits. In that report from the federal Department of Fisheries and in the report from the union in Newfoundland, it was said that there were 1,600 families affected by a poor fishing season in that province alone. I am not talking now about the other provinces in Atlantic Canada. Therefore, the Minister had that information on her desk the day before she stood up in the House and gave the answer she did to the question which was put to her.
In answer to my question in which I pointed out that the snow was falling and there were no longer boats out in the water she said she was waiting until the season was completed. She said:
We have made a commitment that we are prepared to go to the limit of $3 million for all constituencies so affected.
Here are the facts, Mr. Speaker. It was a poor fishing season. It was a poor fishing season last year as well, and the Liberal Government approved-throwing money at problems, as the Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) keeps reminding us-a special program whereby fishermen and fish plant workers could receive enough work to qualify for unemployment insurance. In that way they would not have to go on welfare, because they consider drawing welfare is really not right but that unemployment insurance benefits are a legitimate source of income. The Liberal Government approved that special program and the fishermen and the fish plant workers, as they received enough to qualify for unemployment insurance benefits, were laid off.
This year we have the situation where the fishing season was even worse. The Canadian Salt Fish Corporation-there is a measure presently before the House-states that its product is down 15 per cent to 20 per cent because it was a poor fishing
season. The Minister, in responding to that question said that she will increase the allocations for Canada Works up $3 million without knowing that the very constituencies affected were already up to $3 million. She repeated in this House that she would not increase the Canada Works allocations any further and she would bring in a special program.
I would like to remind this Minister, Mr. Speaker, after deriding the former Government for doing what was legitimate, that even if she increased the Canada Works allocation to S3 million, there are rules and regulations in that program which prohibits fishermen from being hired.
I have listened to a lot of debate in this House recently. There was a report concerning women, handicapped people, young people and old people who could not get jobs. Yet a week ago in this House this very Minister tabled qualifications for getting hired on federal works programs which eliminated everyone who had not worked before it eliminated anyone who has been out of the work force for two years; and it eliminated anyone who had had enough gumption to go out and work for a week in the previous two months. That is outrageous, Mr. Speaker.
It is odd that the person writing the report did not discover, or perhaps just did not know, that the Minister would table the guidelines as she did. However, these very guidelines would discriminate against the very fishermen or fish plant workers for whom the Minister says she is going to increase the assistance allocation. To put it very briefly, Mr. Speaker, this Government has refused to bring in a special program in order to assist these poor, unfortunate people who could not afford to buy school books for their children in September of this year; those 1,600 families. That is amazing, Mr. Speaker, because most of them are in Tory ridings. Surely, there must be enough pressure on the Minister of Employment and Immigration (Miss MacDonald) to get her to change her mind.
The Minister has said she is going to increase to $3 million the allocation to take care of those people, at the same time realizing that the worst hit constituencies were already up to $3 million. The Minister said in this House that some of the fishermen have now received their unemployment insurance benefits. They received ten weeks, and I will tell you how, Mr. Speaker. They went out day after day in rough weather to get an $80 stamp. That is what they had to do because they knew no program was coming. They will live throughout the winter, those few fishermen, having their income supplemented by welfare. What a way to treat the primary producers of this nation. It is despicable, Mr. Speaker.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jean-Guy Hudon (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Employment and Immigration
subtopic: UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE-NEWFOUNDLAND FISHERMEN- REQUEST FOR ASSISTANCE
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as indicated by the Minister of Employment and Immigration (Miss MacDonald), and I will repeat her words, we have been monitoring very closely the Newfoundland Fishermen issue. The most recent figures provided by the Department of Fisher-
November 22, 1984

ies and Oceans have been confirmed by the United Fishery and Food Workers' Union. They indicate that 1,100 fishermen might not-might not, I repeat-be eligible for unemployment insurance this winter. We will have more information in November when fishermen's unemployment applications are processed.
As the Hon. Member knows, funds have been allocated under the Canada Works Program. Electoral ridings are eligible for the $3 million in case of need and if the maximum amount has not yet been paid out. If the Hon. Member knows of any specific cases where fishermen continue to be ineligible for unemployment insurance, even after the Canada Works projects are set up, I would ask him to bring them to the attention of the Minister of Employment and Immigration.
Canada Works funds were also allocated last fall, to help fishermen become eligible for unemployment insurance benefits during the winter. However, the program to which the
Adjournment Debate
Hon. Member is referring was probably the special allowance provided in the spring for fishermen who were prevented from fishing during the normal fishing season because of ice conditions. Allowances were paid through the Canada Employment and Immigration Center but did not come out of the Unemployment Insurance Fund.
We feel that increasing Canada Works funds for Newfoundland will help many fishermen become eligible for unemployment insurance benefits this winter. If upon termination of the projects the number of insurable weeks is still insufficient, the Minister is prepared to review the situation.
